editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE SIR THOMAS COVENTREY KNIGHT, L. KEEPER OF THE Great Seale of England, One of his Maie≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Priuie Coun≈øell.
div.p:
THe Author of this Excellent Hi≈øtorie was the ≈øame wi≈øe and worthy Frier, who of late with ≈øo great iudgement and fidelitie hath reuealed vnto the
World that piece of the My≈øtery of Iniquity, tho≈øe Arcana Imperij Pontificij, in the History of the Trent Councell, which ≈øhall bee a la≈øting Monument of his memorie, and Fame to all Po≈øterity. His owne Countrey-men knew well how to value and reward his Vertues, iudging him a Per≈øon capable to a≈øsi≈øt in their Highe≈øt Coun≈øels of State: But at Rome his goodne≈ø≈øe ea≈øily merited the extreme hatred of the Courtiers (though hee liued and died in the outward CoÃÑmunion of that Church,) ≈øo farre, that they ≈øentenced and martyred him in his Picture (being defeated in their reall attempt vpon his Per≈øon) as a Mezzo Lutherano, an Heretique, ≈øuch as are, in their account, all tho≈øe that cannot beleeue
that thirteenth Article of the Roman Creed, Sube≈ø≈øe Romano Pontifici &c. e≈øt de nece≈øsitate ≈øalutis. In the≈øe Annals Your Lord≈øhip may ≈øee the naturall Power of all Soueraigne Princes and Law-giuers, fir≈øt rudely a≈ø≈øaulted by Him who will needs bee Perpetuall Dictator at Rome, and giue Lawes at his plea≈øure to all the World; then generou≈øly a≈ø≈øerted and vindicated by that mo≈øt Prudent and Illu≈øtrious Common-wealth, which though one of the mo≈øt aged in Europe, hath ≈øtill maintained it ≈øelfe fre≈øh and flouri≈øhing, amid≈øt all the Confu≈øions and Alterations of Italy; an indubitable argument that it is a Body well complexion'd, and foundded vpon ≈øollide Rules of good Policy. The Tran≈ølator pre≈øumes to
put this Piece into Your Honourable Hands, not as prizing ≈øo highly his owne performance (which is but weake like Him≈øelfe, then whom none is more con≈øcious of infirmities:) but encouraged hereto both by Your Benignity, and by the Dignitie of the Worke it ≈øelfe, from which hee knowes Your Lord≈øhips Wi≈øedome will draw many ≈øerious and important Con≈øiderations. Al≈øo his priuate Intere≈øts binde him publiquely and vpon all occa≈øions to profe≈ø≈øe his very very deepe obligation to Your Honour, ≈øuch as He can neuer ≈øatisfie. He could ≈øpeake largely in Your Prai≈øe, and the common Voice of the People would acquit him from ≈øu≈øpition of flatterie (which naturally Hee abhorres,)
the Kingdome generally being much comforted to ob≈øerue the great Iudgement of our mo≈øt Gracious Soueraigne, and his loue to the Publique in his choice of ≈øo Able and worthy an Officer: But hee forbears, le≈øt He ≈øhould offer violence to Your Mode≈øty, and refers Your Goodne≈ø≈øe to God, and Your owne good Con≈øcience to bee more really recompenced. Finally, Hee euery day heartily ble≈ø≈øes God to ≈øee this Church ≈øo happy in ≈øo great a Friend, and an Example of Religion, and this State in ≈øo great a Patrone and Patterne of Equity. The ≈øame God of Grace continue long Your Lord≈øhip an In≈øtrument of his Glory, and multiply all his Mercies vpon Your owne Per≈øon, Your mo≈øt Religious
Ladie, and Your Hopefull Children. This is the Prayer of

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips ≈øincerely and thankefully deuoted C. P.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
THe Ambition of Princes hath many goodly ≈øhrouds and di≈øgui≈øements; it v≈øually borrowes the fal≈øe beautie of apparences to bleare vulgar eyes, and to elude or pacifie Opinions: But among the re≈øt it hath none either more potent to this effect, or more malicious than when it gilds it ≈øelfe with the colour of Religion, and a≈ø≈øumes the couerture of Pietie. For this is to write God him≈øelfe the Author of all their v≈øurpations, and to ca≈øt vpon that Infinite Iu≈øtice the patronage, the ≈øhame and di≈øhonour of all their publique Robberies, Oppre≈øsions, and Violences. The Pagan Tyrants of old, though they were not more iu≈øt, yet they were more mode≈øt: They had a more venerable conceit of their Gods (≈øuch as they were) then to entitle them to their owne vniu≈øt actions And therefore when by plaine force or fraud, they tooke from lawfull Princes their Crownes and Kingdoms, they profe≈ø≈øed ingenuou≈øly herein to neglect Piety and Iu≈øtice,
hence that Maxime of theirs‚Äîregnandi caus√¢ violandum e≈øt ius, In caeteris rebus pietatem colas. But among vs Chri≈øtians (to the great blemi≈øh of our mo≈øt holy Faith, and the ≈øcandall of Infidels,) wee haue Two great Catholiques, the one a King, the other a Bi≈øhop, who vnder the faire pretence of Piety haue already inuaded a great part of the World, and in their hopes deuoured it all. The former vnder ≈øhadow of Conuerting the We≈øt-Indies hath depopulated them, baptized tho≈øe poore Paynims in their owne bloud, and to make them Chri≈øtians, hath made them no men. And no doubt it was meerely re≈øpects of Con≈øcience and pure zeale for the Church again≈øt Here≈øie, that moued him to ≈øeaze vpon Nauar, Sicily, &c. to imbroile all France with that (damned) Holy League, and now lately to depriue the Gri≈øons of the Valtoline, and that mo≈øt Noble Prince Palatine of his ancient Inheritance. For it ≈øeemes it is a part of their Go≈øpell in Spaine, that the Catholique Faith cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt without the Catholique Monarchy. And it ≈øeemes they are aliue againe, whom that noble Britaine of old in Tacitus called‚Äîraptores Orbis‚Äîquos non Oriens non Occidens ≈øatiaucrit‚Äîauferre, trucidare, fal≈øis nominibus Imperium, atque vbi ≈øolitudinem faciunt pacem appellant. I am ≈øure who≈øoeuer lookes vpon the pre≈øent mi≈øerable Face of Europe, euery where mourning and labouring vnder his Armes or Artifices, will confe≈ø≈øe that if he
aduance his Conque≈øts a little further (though euery good man will abhor the Omen, and humbly pray the Lord God to auert it,) he will quickly lead all Europe in triumph, make the Pope him≈øelfe become his Chaplaine, turne all Kingdoms into his Prouinces, & Plant them with Colonies of Moores or Indians, all Princes to be petty Officers of his Hou≈øe, and ≈øend the meane people to dig in his Mines, or to fi≈øh Him ≈øome Pearles in America. The wor≈øt is, he preuailes not ≈øo much by his owne Vertue, as by our ≈øinfull ≈øecurity, who are become
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , fallen from the innocence, wi≈ødome, and courage of our Aunce≈øtors: if betimes we looke not to it, our Po≈øterity will haue occa≈øion to cur≈øe vs for betraying their Liberty. The Lord of Ho≈øts goe out with the Armies of our mo≈øt religious and worthy Soueraigne, and ≈øend him Coun≈øell and Strength and good Succe≈ø≈øe in the≈øe his iu≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary Warres, ≈øo as all that hate Him may flee before Him.

For the Other who qualifies him≈øelfe the Catholique Bi≈øhop, its a pitty to reade how he inchanted the World in former times with the formidable names of S. Peters Keyes and his Swords, of the Romane Succe≈ø≈øion and Apo≈øtolique See; his infallible Iudgement and vnlimited Iuri≈ødiction. How by degrees he plucked vp all ancient Pales and Boundaries, extended his Dioce≈ø≈øe
all ouer the Earth, and at length inclo≈øed all Chri≈øtendome within the walls of Rome. His fir≈øt attempt to this purpo≈øe was to depre≈ø≈øe his Concurrent of Con≈øtantinople in ≈øpite of ≈øo many Canons of ancient Generall Councels, ≈øo iealous of their
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Eccle≈øia≈øticall limits, and ≈øo often a≈øsigning to tho≈øe Two Prime Patriarches, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , equall Honour and Authority;) which he ea≈øily compa≈ø≈øed by fauouring the Trea≈øons and Parricides of that v≈øurper Phocas, receiuing from Him in recompence the Title (≈øo much dete≈øted by Gregory 1.) of Oecumenicall Bi≈øhop. After this he contended with all Catholique Bi≈øhops in that quarrell about Images, and again≈øt them all gained his Proce≈ø≈øe in that ridiculous Packe the ≈øecond Synod of Nice. At la≈øt, being encouraged with this great ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, his Arrogance ≈øtill prompting Him
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , he fell to conte≈øt with Emperours them≈øelues, in apparence for Eccle≈øia≈øticall Inue≈øtitures, in truth for Soueraignty: Confounding all Europe with horrible ruines, tumults, and bloud≈øhed, firing all Countries with his Excommunications & Interdicts, which were indeed but Igues fatui, neuer penetrating (contrary to the lightning of Heauen) but where they found no re≈øi≈øtance, and receiuing all their heat and vigor from the cold patience and weakne≈ø≈øe of the Times, and a≈ø≈øuming to him≈øelfe a va≈øte power to dethrone Kings at
his plea≈øure, and to to≈ø≈øe their Crownes like ≈øo many Tennis-Balles: Till, in conclu≈øion, he was ≈øaluted Dominus Deus no≈øter Papa, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , no more a Mortall, and had ≈øei≈øed him≈øelfe as in fee of all Churches and Kingdomes, all Bi≈øhops being now his Curates, and all Kings (in his account) his Va≈ø≈øals and Homagers. With ≈øuch lewd impo≈øtures and holy trum peries he cheated our innocent Forefathers, hauing fir≈øt blindfolded them by withdrawing the diuine light of Scriptures, and by planting a fatall ignorance of all good Letters, which (together with the ≈øuper≈øtition which followed) ≈øo amu≈øed and enfeebled all Spirits, that they were rendred capable of any (ab≈øurde≈øt) impre≈øsions. But it exceeds all wonder that he ≈øhould yet ≈øtill continue to put his iugling tricks upon this Age of Light and Learning, wherein he hath beene ≈øo often convicted and ≈øtigmatized for a Coozener: Vnle≈ø≈øe haply his lanizaries the Ie≈øuites make Him beleeue that they haue ≈øubdued all Peoples under his Blind Obedience, and taught them (like uncleane Bea≈øts or like Them≈øelues) to ≈øwallow his mor≈øels without chewing, to receiue his Commandements without di≈øputing. If He nouri≈øh any ≈øuch impudent hopes, the ≈øtout Venetians (as appeares in this Hi≈øtory) will helpe to di≈øabu≈øe Him, and lend Him ≈øpectacles (if He be not ≈øtarke blind) to ≈øee his Error. Be≈øides, tho≈øe Excellent Wits of that Republique (all
collected in the Latine by Golda≈øtus) which vpon this occa≈øion canua≈øed the Controuer≈øies, haue ≈øo learnedly nullified the≈øe Papall preten≈øions and Cen≈øures, that hereafter his wi≈øe≈øt cour≈øe will be to play the≈øe parts vpon the ≈øtages of Iapan or Mexico among his new ≈øilly Conuerts, not in Europe where an A≈ø≈øe is ea≈øily knowne from a Lyon, and his Rodomantades in this kinde will finde as much credit as Lucians true Hi≈øtories. In one word, We are told in this Hi≈øtory (pag. 117.) by an Oracle, our late ble≈ø≈øed Soueraigne of Immortall Memory, (and it is a truth as cleare as if it were Solis radio ≈øcriptum, in the Prouerbe of Tertullian, written with a Sunne-beame,) that the onely pride of this V≈øurper hath bred and fomented all Contentions in point of Religion, mi≈øerably difioynted the Catholique Church into ≈øo many fragments and pieces, and ≈øtill keeps fre≈øh the bleeding wounds and ruptures of Chri≈øtendome; While≈øt he is ob≈øtinate in de≈øpite of God and Men to erect his ab≈øolute Monarchy, and to that end urges euery Canon of the Trent Councell more rigorou≈øly than any part of Canonicall Scripture, and all tho≈øe new Articles of Pope Pius the fourth his Creed more then the old ones of the Apo≈øtles: While≈øt be di≈ødaines to acknowledge his Humanitie by exempting Him≈øelfe from Error, obtrudes vpon the World euery fantafie of his Court for a Catholique veritie,
and pre≈øumes (as if he had the keeping of the Booke of Life) to raze out of the Communion of Saints all that are not of his Schi≈ømaticall Congregation, as if Fides Catholica were now nothing but Fides Vrbica, or Vrbana, and as if they had no part in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, who are not in the part of Pope Vrban, iu≈øt the old iargon of Donatus, one of the Patriarchs of Popery.)

Now for the≈øe broyles at Venice, it had beene a Miracle (far exceeding all that euer were wrought by Father Xauier, or any of his Comperes in the Ea≈øt or We≈øt Indies,) if the Ie≈øuites had not beene tampering with their bellowes in this fire. Although in the euent, (by the iu≈øt prouidence of God) all the ≈ømoake was blowne into their owne Eyes, and their owne Ne≈øts by this fire con≈øumed. For this wi≈øe Republique ob≈øeruing the ≈øeditious humor of the≈øe wicked Spirits meerely incompatible with the Peace of any State) thought be≈øt to coniure them out of their Dominions, and accordingly by an irreuocable Decree (which will not be ≈øo ea≈øily demoli≈øhed as that Pyramide erected once at Paris to their infamy) bani≈øhed them for euer: Grounding their Iudgement vpon this euidence (pag. 138.) that the Ie≈øuites haue beene the ≈øole Authors of all di≈øcords, di≈øorders, and mi≈øeries in this Age thorowout all Kingdomes of the World. And certainly few parts of the Habitable Earth haue e≈øcaped their bloudy and violent Practi≈øes; neither
is it po≈øsible in Europe to name that Countrey (≈øaue only Spaine and the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, their great Patrons) wherein tho≈øe re≈øtle≈ø≈øe Furies haue not beene kindling Combu≈øtions, and plotting the diui≈øion (and con≈øequently the de≈øolation) of the State. Without que≈øtion, when they goe to their owne place, the Deuill is wi≈øe enough to pin vp the≈øe Bro√ºillons in ≈øome clo≈øe dungeon by them≈øelues, for otherwi≈øe they would di≈øturbe Hell it ≈øelfe, and Satan ≈øhould haue no peace in his owne Kingdome, which (as our Sauiour tells vs) if it be diuided cannot ≈øtand. Nor doe they onely act but teach Sedition; giue rules of di≈øloyalty, periury, and parricide; make their Di≈øciples beleeue that Rebellion is a vertue, and the murthering of a Prince a merit; that a Clarke cannot be a Traitor, becau≈øe he is no Subiect; and that a King ought not to raigne or liue if he ≈øerue not the Pope, who hath (directly or indirectly, it matters not) all Power in Heauen and Earth. The≈øe are the Maximes of their Cabale; aboue 30. Ie≈øuites of late haue beene openly challenged by the Vniuer≈øity of Paris (in the name of all the others of France) to haue publi≈øhed the≈øe execrable Doctrines, tending to the ruine of Mankinde. And le≈øt they ≈øhould want Actors for any of their Tragedies in time of need, they haue their Chambers of Meditation, which are clearely ≈øo many Seminaries of King-killers and A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øins: wherein their weake or wilde
Nouices are fir≈øt frighted out of their Wits, and ≈øo animated and prepared for any (the mo≈øt de≈øperate) enterpri≈øes. Neuer was Sect ≈øo iu≈øtly and vniuer≈øally hated and feared: All Nations dete≈øt and ≈øu≈øpect Them, yet ≈øtill they pro≈øper. So ≈øtrangely, that who≈øoeuer ≈øeriou≈øly eyes their Power and Practi≈øes, will ≈øee they doe but equiuocate with their owne Ma≈øters, the Pope and Spaine: pretending to be their Factors and In≈øtruments, but indeed hauing their right eye vpon Them≈øelues. So that if the World do not quickly re≈øolue to preuent Them by an vtter aboli≈øhing of this pe≈øtilent Vermin, the next Age will ≈øee the Ie≈øuites plant both the Catholique Crownes vpon the Head of their Generall. In the meane while we ≈øleepe, and which is wor≈øe, we ≈øinne; Neuer more need we had to be at peace with God, and well vnited among our ≈øelues, being threatened with ≈øo many dangers and Enemies abroad. What then can wee iudge of ≈øo many new Doctrines in the Church, ≈øo many old ≈øinnes in the State, but that they are certaine ≈øymptomes (and indeed Cau≈øes) of our approaching ruine, which in all humane iudgement cannot be auoided, vnle≈ø≈øe the Lord as he is wont) work ≈øome Miracle in our pre≈øeruation. He hath long wooed vs with innumerable vnparalell'd mercies, and of late ≈øcourged vs with a furious Mortality: but our dull & dead hearts are ≈øtill ≈øtupid and in≈øen≈øible, we do not turne to him that ≈ømiteth vs, we doe not meet our God by Repentance,
we returne nothing but in≈øolence and ingratitude. We de≈øpi≈øe his Mercy, and defie his Iu≈øtice; we ≈øcoffe at Holine≈ø≈øe in ≈øtead of honouring and imitating it, we laugh at ≈øinne, in ≈øtead of lamenting it, and tho≈øe are called Manners with vs, which our hone≈øt Fore-fathers would haue counted Vices. Our Athei≈øme, Sacriledge, Luxury, Exce≈ø≈øe, Pride, Vnthankfulne≈ø≈øe, open Prophanene≈ø≈øe, &c. crie downe vengeance vpon our heads, and will doubtle≈ø≈øe make vs the example of Gods indignation to all the World, (as we haue beene formerly of his loue,) the pity of our Friends, the hi≈øsing and reproach of our Enemies round about vs. Tunc votorum praecipuus locus, quum ≈øpei nullus. All you that loue and feare God, and that tremble vnder the expectation of his wrath, giue him no re≈øt, ≈øtand vp in the breach, and qua≈øi manu fact√¢ Deum ambientes, a≈ø≈øault him with your prayers, helps to quench this fire of his anger with your teares of ≈øorrow. Giue not ouer weeping, repenting, and praying, till you haue receiued a gracious an≈øwer, till the ≈øinnes of our Nation be pardoned, his imminent iudgements auerted, his ancient fauours recouered; till he haue rebuked Satan, and trodden him vnder our feet, till he haue fru≈øtrated the bloudy hopes and de≈øires of the Enemies of his Truth, till he build vp the breaches, rai≈øe the ruines, binde vp the wounds of his Sion: Saying with Daniel, O Lord God which art great and fearefull, which keepe≈øt couenant
and mercy towards them that loue thee and keepe thy Commandements: We haue ≈øinned, and committed iniquitie, and haue done wickedly, we haue rebelled and haue departed from thy Precepts, and from thy Commandements. For wee would not obey thy Seruants, thy Mini≈øters which ≈øpake in thy Name, to our Kings, to our Princes, to our Fathers, and to all the People of the Land. O Lord righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe belongeth vnto thee, and to vs open ≈øhame and confu≈øion of face, as appeareth this day. Yet compa≈ø≈øion and forgiuene≈ø≈øe is with the Lord, albeit we haue rebelled again≈øt him. Now therefore, O Lord, heare the prayers of thy ≈øeruants and their ≈øupplications, and cau≈øe thy Face to ≈øhine vpon thy Sanctuary, that lyeth wa≈øte for thy Names ≈øake. O Lord heare, O Lord forgiue, O Lord con≈øider and doe it, deferre not for thine owne ≈øake, O my God, for thy Name is called vpon thy City, and vpon thy People.

body.head: THE HISTORY OF THE QVARRELS OF POPE PAVL 5. With The State of ∆≤enice.

div.head: First Booke.
div.p:
POpe PAVL the fift, was addicted from his youth and nouri≈øhed in tho≈øe ≈øtudies, which haue no other end but to acquire vnto the Pope the Spirituall and Temporall Monarchie of all the world: and to aduance the order of the Clergie ≈øo farre, as not only to exempt them from all power and
iuri≈ødiction of Princes, but further to exalt them about Kings them≈øelues, and to ≈øubmit vnto them Secular men in all kindes of ≈øeruices and commodities. Being come to perfect age, hee had yet better means to manage tho≈øe armes by which this doctrine is maintained, For hauing exerci≈øed the office of Auditor of the Chamber, a charge altogether agreeable to his nature and inclination, in as much as the power attributed to that Magi≈øtrate, is, to be Sententiarum & cen≈øurarum intus & extr√† latarum vniuer≈øalis executor; He employed him≈øelfe in this charge more exactly than any of his Predece≈ø≈øours, ≈øo that more Monitories and Citations were thundered out by him, during the fiue yeares of his office, than had beene in any fiftie yeares before.

In that while, he conceiued a vehement de≈øire of vengeance again≈øt tho≈øe who ≈øeemed to him to bring ≈øome empeachment to the libertie or (to ≈øpeake more properly) licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of per≈øons Eccle≈øia≈øticall, and to the free and arbitrary exerci≈øe of Excommunication. But becau≈øe the de≈øire of reuenge is extingui≈øhed, or at lea≈øt repre≈ø≈øed, when it is directed again≈øt Per≈øons ≈øo potent and eminent, that there is no hope to effect it: his courage and re≈øolutions were bent
not ≈øo much again≈øt Kings and Monarches, as again≈øt Republiques or popular Common-wealthes, becau≈øe that con≈øidering the Gouernours thereof in their priuate per≈øons (in which re≈øpect they are without power,) he might hope to attaine his end, how≈øoeuer they were ioyned in one body, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted by authoritie, which accompanieth publique forces. But aboue all, he had a particular de≈øigne of reuenge again≈øt the State of Venice, as well becau≈øe it alone ≈øu≈øtaineth the dignitie, and hath the true markes of a Prince, independent, as becau≈øe the Eccle≈øia≈øtiques haue no dealing in that E≈øtate, and yet further, it alone (among all Princes) doth not giue pen≈øions to any of the Court of Rome: which being by them interpreted a contempt, is the cau≈øe that they cary all an e≈øpeciall hatred, and nouri≈øh in them≈øelues an euill will again≈øt that State. Hereupon being aduanced vnto the Papacie, he propo≈øed no other thing for his end, but to enlarge the Eccle≈øia≈øticall authoritie, or (as he termed it) to re≈øtore it vnto that condition from which it was fallen by the negligence of this Predece≈ø≈øors, and particularly of Clement 8. Wherefore his fir≈øt purpo≈øe was to e≈øtabli≈øh a Congregation at Rome, who≈øe only charge and ≈øtudie ≈øhould be
to con≈øider o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ whereby this authoritie might
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and augmented; or at lea≈øt by cramining all writings vpon the≈øe matters to rai≈øe new difficulties, and to prepare occa≈øions for his Succe≈ø≈øours to giue perfection vnto that which he could not fini≈øh, and in the meane while to mortifie the pre≈øumption (as he called it) of Secular E≈øtates. Be≈øides, he imagined that to bring this his de≈øigne to perfection, it was nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend into all Kingdomes and Courts of Cat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Princes ≈øuch Nuntio's as were enclin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ the like thoughts. That which ≈øtraight wayes he began to execute, by changing the
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
formerly imployed; and particularly „Äà‚óä„Äâ to Venice Horatio Matthei, Bi≈øhop of Gi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
a man ≈øo pa≈ø≈øionate in this cau≈øe, that he bl ‚Ä¢ ≈øhed not to ≈øay vnto the Duke in full a≈ø≈øembly that Alines and other workes of pietie, the frequ ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing of Sacraments, and all other good and Chri≈øtion actions, ad nihilum valent vltra, were nothing auaileable, if men did not fauour the Eccle≈øia≈øticall libertie: the≈øe were his words. And in many familiar di≈øcour≈øes which he had with diuers per≈øons, he was wont to ≈øay, that he had heard the pietie of the City of Venice often
„Äà‚óä„Äâ amply commended, by him≈øelfe
could perceiue but little; con≈øidering that Chri≈øtian perfection doth not con≈øi≈øt in almes deeds and deuotions, but in exalting the Eccle≈øia≈øticall iuri≈ødiction, which is the true ciment of that perfection. And many times he would intimate that he had beene ≈øent by the Pope in that charge of his Nuntio, for to receiue martyrdome (if it were needfull) in defence of the autho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tie of the See Apo≈øtolique. But the vanitie of this man, ≈øo de≈øirous of Martyrdome, was not without ≈øome mixture of ambition, and de≈øire of command. For if any one did reply again≈øt him with rea≈øon, or contradict his di≈øcour≈øes vpon this ≈øubject, his ordinary an≈øwer was (as if it had beene a forme of ≈øpeech or a le≈ø≈øon giuen him) here I am Pope, and I will be obeyed. But the Pope did not crect this Congregation according to his fir≈øt de≈øeigne, being aduerti≈øed that by this meanes hee ≈øhould too manife≈øtly di≈øcouer his intentions, which might bring iealou≈øie to all Princes, and cau≈øe them to proiect ≈øome remedies, and ≈øo it might produce effects quite contrary to his meaning; as it fell out with Clement 8. who by founding a Congregation vpon the affaires of England, excited the ≈øpirit of that King to ob≈øerue more narrowly the cariage of
the Catholiques of his Kingdome: which was the cau≈øe that their enterpri≈øes were afterward much more thwarted. And againe, the Pope would not put in execution (during the fir≈øt Monthes of his Papacy) any one of tho≈øe particulars which were alreadie de≈øigned, becau≈øe being fir≈øt weakened by the vehemence of his hopes and ioyes, hee
‚Ä¢ as afterward a≈ø≈øailed with a grieuous melancholy, accompanied with a ≈øtrong apprehen≈øion of death, which he feared would ≈øeaze vpon him within a few dayes. This feare was more encrea≈øed by a rumour di≈øper≈øed thorow Rome, that the Image of our Lady de Subiacco had ≈øweated; which v≈øually happens (as the vulgar beleeue) for to aduerti≈øe the Popes that their death is at hand. And further, a Flemmi≈øh Astrologer had foretold that in March Pope Clement 8. was to die, and that after him ≈øhould be elected one Leo, and then one Paul, who ≈øhould liue but a ≈øhort time. Be≈øides, this Pope by nature was timorous, and much inclined to giue credit vnto Diuinations, which he entertained vpon all occurrences and accidents. This perturbation of ≈øpirit held him fiue Months in ≈øuch extremitie, that all things affrighted him; in ≈øo much that he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed his Cooke and his Caruer, who had
long time ≈øerued him; and if any per≈øons of ba≈øe and meane condition and vnknowne, did pre≈øent him with any memoriall or petition as hee pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øtreets, very often hee let them fall to the ground, fearing le≈øt they might bee empoy≈øoned. Being thus vexed with ≈øu≈øpitions, his de≈øigne touching the enlargement of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Libertie was neglected.

But in the Month of September after his promotion to the Papacie, his friends and kin≈ømen found a remedie for this feare; hauing made a great a≈ø≈øembly of all the A≈øtrologers and other Fortune-tellers of Rome, in the hou≈øe of the Lord Iohn Francis, brother to his Holine≈ø≈øe, who concluded by their rules that the time of ≈øome perils threatned by the influences was pa≈øt, and that therefore he might now liue many yeares. His feare being thus remoued, he re≈øumed againe his fir≈øt and ordinary thoughts of augmenting the Eccle≈øia≈øticall iuri≈ødiction.

He began to moue the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King that the Councell of Trent might be receiued in his Kingdome. In Spaine he procured that the Ie≈øuites might be exempted from paying any Tithes. At Naples he wrought in ≈øuch ≈øort that Iohn Francis de Ponte Marqui≈øe of Morcone, called
the Regent de Ponte, was ≈øent to Rome, as puni≈øhable in the Inqui≈øition, for hauing condemned to the Gallies a Booke≈øeller, for a matter which the Inqui≈øitor pretended to belong to his cogni≈øance. Hee tooke from the Religious of Malta the collation of certaine Commanderies, conferring them vpon the Cardinall Borghe≈øe. He rai≈øed many difficulties to the Duke of Parma, as well for the impo≈øts which he had put vpon his Subiects of Parma in the ab≈øence of the Bi≈øhop, as for the fact of Count Albert Scotto, and al≈øo for other things which the Pope pretended to haue beene enterpri≈øed again≈øt the Bull, in caena Domini. Moreouer, he had ≈øome differences with the Duke of Sauoy, not only becau≈øe his Officers tooke knowledge, and gaue iudgement in the temporalty of Benefices, but al≈øo becau≈øe Laiques a≈ø≈øi≈øt at the Office of the Inquifition; but e≈øpecially by rea≈øon of an Abbey which the Duke had con≈øerred on the Cardinall Pio. All things being put in deliberation, the Duke changing the per≈øon named to the Abbey, placed therein a Nephew of his Holine≈ø≈øe, ≈øome what to appea≈øe him.

But none of the≈øe attempts ≈øucceeding to his minde, in the beginning of October, two occa≈øions were offered, not only of them≈øelues very
proper for the end which the Pope pretended, but very commodious, as being ≈øo many degrees and meanes to open him a pa≈ø≈øage to greater matters. The one was, that the Republique of Luca con≈øidering that many of their Citizens hauing changed their Religion, had retired them≈øelues into Prote≈øtant countries; in this regard they had publi≈øhed an Edict, by which all their ≈øubjects were forbidden to haue any commerce, or to treat in any fa≈øhion what≈øoeuer with ≈øuch per≈øons: an Edict which doubtle≈ø≈øe had beene highly commended by ≈øome former Popes. But this man, after it had beene repre≈øented vnto him, approued the law in it ≈øelfe; but ≈øaid neuerthele≈ø≈øe that the Republique of Luca had no authority to make any ≈øuch ordinance which touched Religion (how≈øoeuer it were in it ≈øelfe good and holy,) for as much as Laiques haue not any power to decree in matter of Religion, although the Law be in fauour thereof. And therefore he ab≈øolutely commanded that the Edict ≈øhould be ra≈øed out of their Records, hauing an intention to make another (the ≈øame in ≈øub≈øtance) but to publi≈øh it by his Pontificall authoritie. The other was, that the Republique of Genoa being aduerti≈øed that the Gouernours
of certaine Lay Fraternities, in≈øtituted by deuotion, had not di≈øpen≈øed the Reuenew with requi≈øite fidelitie, re≈øolued to examine and renew their accounts; and to this effect commanded that the Bookes ≈øhould bee brought vnto the Duke. And in the ≈øame Citie there happened a thing of much greater importance, occa≈øioned by a new in≈øtitution of an Oratorie of Secular per≈øons, in the Hou≈øe of the Ie≈øuites, for Chri≈øtian exerci≈øes; wherein they of that Congregation con≈øpired not to fauour any but of their owne Society in the di≈øtribution of Magi≈øtracies. Whereof the State hauing notice, by publique authoritie they tooke order to prohibite all ≈øuch A≈ø≈øemblies. The≈øe Decrees (which indeed commended the pietie of that Republique, as de≈øirous to prouide again≈øt the euill husbanding of temporall goods giuen to pious v≈øes, and to preuent all vnlawfull conuenticles and a≈ø≈øemblies, which vnder pretext of Religion tend to the ruine of CoÃÑmmon-wealths,) were not expounded in the true ≈øence, nor well accepted by the Pope; but contrarily he was much offended, and gaue the Republique to vnder≈øtand, that the≈øe Ordinances were again≈øt the Liberty Eccle≈øia≈øtical, and therefore expre≈ø≈øely he enioyned them to reuoke their
Edicts, otherwi≈øe he threatned to thunder out his Cen≈øures. Hee made great in≈øtance to the State of Venice, that they would ≈øuccour the Emperour with money for the warre of Hungarie again≈øt the Turke, offering him≈øelfe (in ca≈øe the Senate ≈øhould make difficultie, for feare of prouoking again≈øt them≈øelues ≈øo pui≈ø≈øant an Enemie) to receiue it ≈øecretly, and pa≈ø≈øe it vnderhand, that it ≈øhould not be perceiued. In which treatie hee and his Nuntio v≈øed a forme of di≈øcour≈øe, not like as when one Prince repre≈øents vnto another their common intere≈øts, but like one which demandeth ≈øome extraordinary contributions from his ≈øubiects. And therefore after ≈øome mode≈øt words of an≈øwer, at la≈øt for a finall re≈øolution the Senate ≈øaid, that, for the con≈øeruation of their E≈øtates they were forced to make great expen≈øes, and to prouide for many diffidences, which hindred that they could not apply them≈øelues to any new enterpri≈øes; that it was nece≈ø≈øary fir≈øt of all to ≈øettle a perfect intelligence among Chri≈øtian Princes, to the end that hauing quitted all ≈øu≈øpitions, they might (being well vnited) entend the oppre≈ø≈øion of that common Enemie; that when≈øoeuer any ouerture vnto a good Vnion ≈øhould be offered, the State
would not be the la≈øt that ≈øhould take armes again≈øt the enemies of Chri≈øtianitie. This an≈øwer ≈øeemed ≈øtrange vnto the Pope, as per≈øwading him≈øelfe (conformably to the doctrine of the moderne Canoni≈øts) that he might command any Prince to doe what≈øoeuer he thinkes expedient for the common good of Chri≈øtendome: neuerchele≈ø≈øe, he iudged not meet to ground his Quarrell vpon this, but vpon ≈øome other occa≈øion, which (in pretence at lea≈øt) might be more ≈øpirituall and trench more neerely vpon the See Apo≈øtolique. Wherefore, fir≈øt onely in generall termes he treated that the Eccle≈øiasticall libertie might not be in any fa≈øhion violated, but rather that iuri≈ødiction re≈øtored entire: this was the talke of his Nuntio in Venice, and of him≈øelfe at Rome to the Emba≈ø≈øador of the Signiory. After, comming to particulars, hee mentioned ≈øome affaires concerning Nauigation, and the impo≈øition vpon oyles, and touching an exchange on the coa≈øt of Romagna for the Marqui≈øate of Ancona; a≈ø≈øaying by all meanes to make the State receiue his commandements. Further, he propo≈øed the reuocation of an Ordinance made by the Senate the eleuenth of December MDCIIII. forbidding the Subiects of the Signiory to ≈øet
forth any Ve≈ø≈øels by ≈øea, or to make any a≈ø≈øurances or companies for the traffique of any merchandize what≈øoeuer (to be exported out of the State of Venice into foraine countries,) vnle≈ø≈øe fir≈øt it pa≈ø≈øed by Venice; alledging that this would hinder the great importations and abundance in the E≈øtate of the Church, and by con≈øequent was again≈øt the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Libertie. But being an≈øwered, that euery Prince commands his ≈øubiects that which may ≈øerue for the commoditie of his owne E≈øtate, without con≈øidering, what may follow thereupon to neighbour Princes, which cannot iu≈øtly be therewith offended, how≈øoeuer they may be in ≈øome ≈øort endamaged: and that when≈øoeuer his Holine≈ø≈øe ≈øhall commaund his Subiects any thing which may turne to the profit of his Gouernment, the State would not take it in euill part, nor e≈øteeme it again≈øt their Libertie: the Pope perceiued by this e≈ø≈øay that thus he could not compa≈ø≈øe his intention, there being not any ≈øhadow of pretext, to fetch this controuer≈øie within the bounds of things Spirituall. For this rea≈øon, ≈øo ≈øoone as he could apprehend an occa≈øion, which might more probably be thought Spirituall, leauing the re≈øt, he ≈øetled his proiects and purpo≈øes wholly vpon this.

The occa≈øion was, that at Vicenza, one Scipio Sarraceno, Canon there of a Church (who had with great contempt defaced the Seale of the Magi≈øtrate, which was put to, for the cu≈øtodie of the Bi≈øhops Court of Chancery, at the reque≈øt of the Chancellor, the See being vacant,) did his vtmo≈øt endeuour to ≈øeduce a Damo≈øell his kin≈øwoman; and preuailing not with her, after he had long mole≈øted and pur≈øued her in publique, and euen in the Church, at la≈øt in a de≈øpitefull outrage, he ≈øhamefully defiled her portall and hou≈øe doores with his excrements: for which cau≈øe, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by ≈øome Gentlemen of her family, ≈øhe came to Venice, and there put in her complaint again≈øt this Canon, who being called, readily pre≈øented him≈øelfe. The Canon had a kin≈øman Bi≈øhop of Citta Nuoua, a man very bu≈øie and enterpri≈øing, who ≈øerued in Venice for a Guide and Coun≈øeller to all the Nuntio's and Mini≈øters of the Pope, and by his coun≈øels directed all their actions; and the Nuntio's had expre≈ø≈øe order to communicate with him their Commi≈ø≈øions. By his meanes the Nuntio was moued in this affaire, who both by his owne di≈øpo≈øition was vehemently de≈øirous to procure for the Clergie a licentious exemption, and but a
little before was come to Venice with that de≈øigne. The Nuntio then and this Bi≈øhop ≈øpeedily gaue aduice of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe vnto the Pope, and to the Bi≈øhop of Vienza, who was then in Court: who thereupon treated together, and mutually excited them≈øelues to the defence of the Canon, and of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Libertie. Both the one and the other ≈øpake of this matter to Augustin Nani, Emba≈ø≈øador of the State, with the Pope, a bout the end of October. The Bi≈øhop told him, that the Pope would not endure the empri≈øonment of a Canon, and that hee was by him encouraged to doe the office of a Bi≈øhop; that therefore it were good to giue ≈øatisfaction to his Holine≈ø≈øe, by rendering the pri≈øoner to the Iudge of the Church, the crime being not ≈øo grieuous. But the Pope was much more peremptory; that he would not in any ≈øort permit that Eccle≈øia≈øtiques in any cau≈øe ≈øhould be iudged by Seculars, this being again≈øt the ordinance of the Councell. The Emba≈ø≈øadour aduerti≈øed the State of the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, and whil≈øt he expected their an≈øwer, the Pope againe complaines vnto him in another audience, how that at Venice ≈øince the decea≈øe of Pope Clement 8. they had made a Decree, forbidding Secular men to alienate their goods
to Eccle≈øia≈øtiques; ≈øaying, that how≈øoeuer that law were founded vpon another more ancient, yet this latter was much more ample; that both the one and the other were void, and could not ≈øub≈øi≈øt, as being again≈øt the Canons, again≈øt the Councell, and again≈øt the Lawes Imperiall; that it was ≈øcandalous, and made the condition of Eccle≈øia≈øtiques wor≈øe then of infamous per≈øons; adioyning withall, that they which made that law had incurred the Cen≈øures. The he ≈øame coÃÑ manded his Nuntio to propo≈øe in full Senate. And the Emba≈ø≈øadors of the Republique being come to Rome to congratulate with his Holine≈ø≈øe about the beginning of Nouember,
year 1605 hee repeated vnto them the ≈øame complaints, chargint them at their returne to giue notice thereof vnto the Senate.

In the meane while, they of Genoa, for to ≈øatisfie the Pope, had reuoked the Degree touching the reuiew of the accounts of their Fraternities; but excu≈øed them≈øelues for the other Decree touching the Congregation, which for ≈øecurity of the State was nece≈ø≈øarily to be executed. Which did ≈øo much enrage the Pope, that hee cau≈øed a Monitorie to be imprinted again≈øt that Republique, meanacing the Cardinals of Genoa, that if the
Decree concerning the Oratories were not reuoked, he would forthwith publi≈øh his Excommunication.

The Pope beleeued that by this example the State of Venice would bee induced toyeeld (without v≈øing any reply) to his de≈øires; ≈øtrongly conceiuing that they would willingly abandon their liberty to auoid their trouble, e≈øpecially, if they were taken before they had time to deliberate. And therefore without expecting an an≈øwer to that which the Extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øadors had treated at their returne, or that which the Ordinary had writ to Venice, the Pope a new expo≈øtulated with the Amba≈ø≈øador both touching the impri≈øoned Canon, and the Ordinance formerly mentioned; the matter he exaggerated, ≈øaying, that the Law had beene made vpon Maundie Thur≈øday, and concluded his ≈øpeech, (≈øhewing the Monitory prepared again≈øt them of Genoa,) that he would be obeyed, and that hee would ≈øend to Venice a Breue Exhortatory, and after proceed yet further. The Amba≈ø≈øador repre≈øented to his Holine≈ø≈øe, that the 26. of March (on which day the Law was made) could not fall within the Holy weeke of that yeare; con≈øidering that Ea≈øter day was then the tenth of
April; and praied him that, ≈øince he had required him to write of the≈øe particularities to Venice, and had giuen charge vnto the Amba≈ø≈øadors Extraordinary to treat thereof by word of mouth, he would expect an an≈øwer before hee determined any thing in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. quickly pre≈øented it; but the Pope not willing to reade it in his pre≈øence, as he did the other, only ≈øaid; that the Venetians did iu≈øt like tho≈øe that ≈øtrike fir≈øt, and then complaine; that he would heare the Extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øador, but not treat with him; that if he brought him not ≈øome ≈øatisfaction, he would pa≈ø≈øe on. He added his v≈øuall complaints, that they meant to delay the affaire, and take the benefit of time, of which he was an enemy, not being able to endure any more prolongings. He complained be≈øides, that the Amba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary deferred too long his comming, not becau≈øe he hoped by his pre≈øence to finde or admit any compo≈øition, being already re≈øolued, and fully in his minde determined to pur≈øue again≈øt the Republique the iniuries which they had offered vnto the Church, but becau≈øe hauing ≈øaid to many Mini≈øters of Princes that he would giue audience to that Amba≈ø≈øador, he could not well proceed till fir≈øt he had heard him ≈øpeake: being extreamely vexed to ≈øee daies pa≈ø≈øing without comming to execution. Likewi≈øe he writ a new to his Nuntio's which he had with all Princes, commanding them in his Name to make complaints again≈øt the Republique, which being knowne at Venice; the
Senate re≈øolued to write vnto all Courts, and to ≈øend ample in≈øtructions to all their Amba≈ø≈øadors, to the end that on all occa≈øions they might demon≈øtrate the iu≈øtice of their cau≈øe, with their vniu≈øt vexations by the Pope.

In the end of March, Duodo the Extraordinarie Amba≈ø≈øador arriued at Rome, who was not ≈øuffered to pa≈ø≈øe the fir≈øt Audience in Complements according to the cu≈øtome, but the Pope without other di≈øcour≈øe falling vpon the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe heard him courteou≈øly, yet would not an≈øwer to any particular, although the Amba≈ø≈øador propounded to his con≈øideration the ≈øeuerall rea≈øons pertaining to each Controuer≈øie. But ≈øtaying only on the generall, he ≈øaid; that the exemption of the Eccle≈øiastiques was de iure diuino, and therefore he would not now content him≈øelfe with (what he formerly had propounded) the re≈øtoring only of the one Pri≈øoner: that he would not meddle with things Temporall, but their three Lawes were v≈øurpations; that he was not moued with any pa≈ø≈øion, and that his cau≈øe was the cau≈øe of God: that the Ordinary Amba≈ø≈øador had often repeated vnto him the≈øe ≈øame allegations, but all were of no force: and that he would heare him to doe him a plea≈øure,
but not to depart in any thing from his re≈øolution; that he would be obeyed, and ≈øuch other like di≈øcour≈øes. The Amba≈ø≈øador to ≈øtay a little this torrent, and to giue him time to be thinke him≈øelfe, offered to write to Venice what was his re≈øolution: wherewith the Pope was content, counting in what time the Currier might returne with an an≈øwer, and threatning that hee would not waite one moment longer. Which thing being knowne at Venice, it was re≈øolued that all ≈øhould be communicated vnto the Amba≈ø≈øadours of the Emperour, of France, and of Spaine. The Amba≈ø≈øador of the Emperour ≈øaid that his Ma≈øter de≈øired Peace, and that in ≈øuch matters he would not foment the will of the Pope The Count of Cante-croix approued all the rea≈øons which were repre≈øented to him, by the example of Francke, a County in his Countrey, where the ≈øame things are ob≈øerued. Mon≈øieur de Fre≈øne, Amba≈ø≈øador of France, an≈øwered, that he knew not what to make of the≈øe Pontificall Lawes, by which Princes are forbidden to Gouerne their E≈øtates, and that in all rea≈øon the Repub. ought to preferre their Libertie to all other re≈øpects, for ≈øalus populi ≈øuprema lex e≈øto, the weale of the people ought to be the Soueraigne Law.

Duodo, as the cu≈øtome is, vi≈øited the Cardinals, and had ≈øpeech with all of them touching the differences in que≈øtion; and although they an≈øwered differently, yet it appeared they had no great hand in the affaire, ≈øaue onely that they heard it propounded in the Con≈øi≈øtory vpon the twelfth of December, and the twentieth of February. Duodo did not cea≈øe in other Audiences which the Pope gaue him, to a≈ø≈øay if he could any way a≈ø≈øwage him; hoping that the differences might be reduced to ≈øome termes of accord, if he might finde meanes a little to hinder his Holine≈ø≈øe from his headlong cour≈øes. But the Pope ≈øtill ≈øhewing him≈øelfe re≈øolute, ≈øaying that he had v≈øed a very great patience: that the Senators were ≈øtill more ob≈øtinate, and his condition euery day wor≈øe; for he vnder≈øtood how it was openly ≈øpoken in Venice, that they were not purpo≈øed herein to giue him any ≈øatisfaction, that therefore he could not abandon his reputation: that in the Senate there was not one that vnder≈øtood the≈øe matters, and that they were content to con≈øult thereof with their Doctors, but that hee had written to ≈øuch Per≈øons as were able to ≈øet their Doctors to Schoole, and concluded that he would proceed with his Spirituall Armes;
but in other things he would account of the Venetians as of his children. The Amba≈ø≈øadour hearing his re≈øolution, and knowing it would be to little effect for him to reply, retired him≈øelfe from the Audience with few words, but full of prudence and grauitie.

The day following, the Cardinals of Verona and Vicenza found meanes to in≈øinuate them≈øelues neere the Pope, and to talke with him vpon this ≈øubiect: where they did very good and effectuall offices, exhorting his Holine≈ø≈øe to v≈øe ≈øome delaies: whereto he an≈øwered, that he had deferred but too long; that the offer by him propo≈øed to the Amba≈ø≈øadour Nani, had beene e≈øteemed not worthy an an≈øwer; that he had heard the Extraordinary, although he ≈øpake big: that he had fiue and twenty or thirty Letters from Venice, whereby hee had notice that hee could not hope for any ≈øatisfaction. Yet notwith≈øtanding all this, that he would yet giue terme of foure and twenty dayes, which was enough time to giue them for their repentance. The Cardinals repre≈øented vnto him with many and powerfull words what damage might follow, if the Spirituall armes ≈øhould be contemned. To which the Pope an≈øwered, that then he
would employ the Temporall. And ≈øo without communicating that which he had in minde to many per≈øons, he cau≈øed to draw vp and imprint a Monitory again≈øt the Republique; which after reuiewing and finding it not to his liking, hee changed it, and at la≈øt compo≈øed and made to be imprinted another, dated the 17. of Aprill, purpo≈øing to publi≈øh it that day in Con≈øi≈øtory. But that morning he was found very much troubled in ≈øpirit, and perplexed what he ≈øhould do; and the houre approching, (the Cardinals being already a≈ø≈øembled) he began profoundly to con≈øider within him≈øelfe, whether to proceed as he had determined, or to deferre the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe till ≈øome other time. But the Cardinall Arrigon (who, according to the cu≈øtom of the Cardinals, which haue part in the Gouernment, was not de≈øcended into the Hall with the re≈øt, but was gone vp into the Chamber of his Holine≈ø≈øe with his Nephew, for to accompany him downe,) exhorted him by no meanes to relent. Whereupon againe re≈øoluing vpon his former purpo≈øe, he entred the Con≈øi≈øtory, where he made recitall of his preten≈øions again≈øt the Republique, inlarging his ≈øpeech particularly vpon that Law (by him called) of Farmes Emphyteuticke, although he
≈øaid he had written nothing thereof to Venice, nor tretaed of it with the Amba≈ø≈øador, ≈øaue only that he had told him, he had ob≈øerued it. He adioyned, that he had fir≈øt him≈øelfe ≈øtudyed the≈øe points, then he had conferred thereof with the mo≈øt famous Canoni≈øts, who did conclude that the ordinances of the Republique were contrary to the Authority of the See Apo≈øtolique, and to liberty Eccle≈øia≈øticall, all edging further that they were coÃÑdemned by the Councell of Pope Symmachus, & by that of Lyons vnder Pope Gregory 10. as al≈øo by the Decrees of the Councels or A≈ø≈øemblies of Con≈øtance and Ba≈øil; that this matter had been declared again≈øt Henry 2. King of England, again≈øt the Kings of Ca≈øtile, and again≈øt the Kings Charles the 2. and Charles the 4. That he knew well there were ≈øome Doctors Canoni≈øts, who approued that Law, forbidding the alienation of Lay mens goods in fauour of the Clergie, but that they were of ≈ømall number and account, and ≈øpake again≈øt the common opinion. And in ca≈øe there yet remain'd any doubt, he did then declare that all the≈øe Lawes were contrary to Eccle≈øiasticall Liberty. Be≈øides he cau≈øed to be read a Con≈øtitution of Innocent the third, vpon a certaine Edict of Henry Emperiour of Con≈øtantinople;
and proceeding to ≈øpeake of criminall iudgements again≈øt per≈øons Eccle≈øia≈øticall, hee ≈øaid that the Venetians pretended to haue ≈øome priuiledges, which not with≈øtanding they did extend to places and cau≈øes not compri≈øed in them, euen again≈øt the per≈øons of Bi≈øhops. He commended further his patience, hauing ≈øo long time expected their repentance: by rea≈øon whereof he might, without further delay or granting any longer terme, come to the Interdict; but mitius agendo, hee had deliberated to giue them re≈øpite of foure and twenty daies more; and that he might doe all things canonically, he was content to take the voices and ≈øuffrages of the Cardinals.

Whereupon each one gaue his ≈øuffrage; and fir≈øt the Cardinall Pinelli commended his Holine≈ø≈øe for that he had a≈ø≈øigned foure and twenty daies for terme of re≈øpite, becau≈øe ≈øo much had beene a≈ø≈øigned to Henry 3. King of France. The Card. d'A≈øcoli made a ≈øigne with his head that he was of the ≈øame opinion, without ≈øpeaking word which could be vnder≈øtood, as al≈øo hee had done vnder Clement 8. when the Monitorie again≈øt the Duke Cae≈øar d'E≈øte was publi≈øhed. The Card. of Verona, hauing prai≈øed the zeale of
his Holine≈ø≈øe, who had proceeded (he ≈øaid) in this affaire lent√¢ fe≈øtinatione; he added, that in a Senate compo≈øed of ≈øo great a number of per≈øons, as was that of Venice, things could not be di≈øpatched with ≈øuch ≈øpeedine≈ø≈øe; that it was not good to bee too ha≈øtie again≈øt a Repub. which had well-merited; that the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe might well be yet a while deferred vpon hope thereby to gaine them, and in the meane time men might haue time to weigh their rea≈øons, and he concluded with the≈øe words, Sed differ, habent paruae commoda magnamorae; But defer, holy Father, little delaies ≈øometime bring great commodities. At this word the Pope interpo≈øed and ≈øaid, that he had done nothing of his owne proper iudgement; that he had adui≈øed with learned men, and beene directed by their coun≈øell. Whereupon the Card. replyed, if this were ≈øo he could not contradict that which had beene re≈øolued by his Holine≈ø≈øe. The Cardinall Sauli ≈øaid, that the Venetians had beene too long forborne and heard; that it was meet to v≈øe rigor again≈øt them to make them yeeld; therefore for his part, he thought it good to proceed with courage in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, referring the i≈ø≈øue to God who≈øe cau≈øe was handled. The
Card. of Saint Cecile ≈øaid, that he lamented the condition of the times, which forced his Holine≈ø≈øe to haue recour≈øe to ≈øuch remedies, but withall hee reioyced that in this his Holine≈ø≈øe had not any humane re≈øpect, but aimed onely at the honour of God, and the dignity and liberty of the Church. The Card. Bandini prai≈øed God who had giuen occa≈øion vnto his Holine≈ø≈øe in the beginning of his Papacie to purcha≈øe vnto him≈øelfe an immortall renowne, by re≈øtoring the Eccle≈øiasticall liberty and iuri≈ødiction. The ≈øuffrage of Card. Baronius, grounded vpon that Theme, that the mini≈øtery of S. Peter hath two parts, the one to feed, the other to kill, hath beene ≈øo often publi≈øhed, that it ≈øeemes not needfull here to mention it. The Card. Iu≈øtiniano ≈øaid, that he conformed him≈øelfe to the iudgement of his Holine≈ø≈øe, being iu≈øtly taken vpon a ca≈øe notorious, Notorietate facti & notorietate iuris; that he ≈øaw not what excu≈øe the Venetians could alledge; that to wait any longer ≈øhould be to nouri≈øh them in their ≈øins, and to partake with them; vpon the≈øe rea≈øons he commended the re≈øolution of his Holine≈ø≈øe. The Card Zapata ≈øaid, that the delay of twenty foure daies was too long, and that the
Ecclefia≈øtiques vnder the Venetians were in wor≈øe condition then were the I≈øraelites vnder Pharaoh. The Card. Conti gaue thanks to God who in the≈øe times had giuen a Pope vigorous of age and ≈øtrength, which by his zeale and vertue could and would re≈øtore againe Ecclefia≈øticall liberty and the authority of the See Apo≈øtolique. All the re≈øt with few words con≈øented, or after a repetition of the rea≈øons vrged by the Pope, confirmed them, or amplified the rea≈øons and allegations of the Canoni≈øts. Which being done, they pa≈ø≈øed to Con≈øi≈øtoriall propo≈øitions according to their cu≈øtome. The number of Cardinals pre≈øent in this Con≈øi≈øtorie were forty and one; the Cardinals of Como, Aldobrandin, Santiquattro and Cae≈øis not going that morning.

No other thing could be expected from the Cardinals, but that they would con≈øent to the deliberations of the Pope; ≈øome by their proper inclination being carried to the ≈øame opinion, as being pa≈ø≈øionate for the Ecclefia≈øticall liberty; others becau≈øe their particular intere≈øts (by rea≈øon of the preten≈øions which they might haue vnto the Papacie) forced them to accord; others had not the boldne≈ø≈øe to contradict the Pope in any matter, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øo cut off
the hope of profit from them or theirs; in which regard, one of them excu≈øed him≈øelfe, ≈øaying, that if he had ≈øaid any thing again≈øt the de≈øigne of the Pope, he had much endamaged him≈øelfe without any furtherance to the Republique. And it is a thing without doubt in the Court of Rome, that the Cardinals voices are taken in Con≈øi≈øtorie onely in apparence and by way of ceremonie, in a≈ø much as they are neuer informed of the affaire whereof they are to treat, but of the fact alone which is pre≈øented; or at the mo≈øt they haue no further information then tho≈øe few words which the Pope is plea≈øed to ≈øpeake two ≈øeuerall times in Con≈øi≈øtorie, as hath beene ≈øaid. And not ≈øeldome matters are propounded whereof they neuer heard word. So that the Popes goe with a≈ø≈øurance to propound in Con≈øi≈øtorie what≈øoeuer is to their humour, grounding vpon the cu≈øtome which is among the Cardinals, to con≈øent to all that which is propo≈øed; which is openly derided in the Court of Rome, changing the Latine word (by the figure of agnomination) a≈ø≈øentiri into a≈ø≈øentari.

This Con≈øi≈øtorie thus fini≈øhed, the Monitorie was affixed in the accu≈øtomed places of the City of Rome, and incontinently ≈øcattered euery
where, an infinite number of Copies being imprinted, partly in Latine, and partly in the Italian, which were ≈øent thorowout all the Cities of Italie; and into the State of Venice it ≈øelfe, were di≈øper≈øed a great quantity which had been ≈øent vnto the Ie≈øuites & other Religious (which tooke part with the Pope,) as al≈øo to their friends, accompanying them with ≈øeditious letters. And thus they continued ≈øending during ≈øome weekes, in forme of pacquets or blancs with in≈øcription to any whom≈øoeuer who≈øe name they knew. One thing was much wondred at, that in the vulgar Copie printed in the Vatican, this clau≈øe of the impri≈øonment of the Abbot and the Canon had beene adioyned [And haue committed the knowledge of their cau≈øe vnto the Secular Magi≈øtrate of the Signiory named the Auogardor,] which clau≈øe was not in the Latine copie. That which cau≈øed the wonder was that ≈øuch commi≈ø≈øion was neuer giuen, and men could not penetrate to what end this fal≈øhood could ≈øerue them.

The Monitorie was addre≈ø≈øed to the Patriarches, Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, their Vicars Generall, and to all the Ecclefia≈øtiques Secular and Regular, hauing Ecclefia≈øticall dignitie within the
E≈øtate of the Republique of Venice. The Pope by this Monitorie declared, that ≈øome Months before it was come to his knowledge, that the Duke and Senate of Venice ≈øome yeeres before had made ≈øome Decrees contrary to the authoritie of the See Apo≈øtolique, and again≈øt the Ecclefia≈øticall immunitie: repugnant vnto the Generall Councels, to the Canons and Con≈øtitutions of Popes; and ≈øpecially he made mention in the fir≈øt place of that ordinance in the yeere M DC II. by which Ecclefia≈øticall per≈øons were forbidden to receiue or purcha≈øe goods immoueable, vnder ≈øhadow that them≈øelues were thereof the direct Lords, their right notwith≈øtanding being not hereby impeached. In the ≈øecond place he mentioned that of the yeere M DC III. by which the prohibition to build Churches or other places of deuotion without leaue, was extended to all the State. In the third place, that of the yeere M DC V. which in like manner extended to all the State, a prohibition to alienate for euer any goods immoueable Secular or Lay, to men of the Church. In the fourth place he ≈øpake of the re≈øtraint of the Canon of Vi√ßen√ßa, and the Abbot of Nerue≈øe; adioyning that ≈øome of tho≈øe Lawes aboli≈øhed the
rights which the Church had euer inioyed, and tended to the preiudice of his authoritie, of the rights of the Church, and of the priuiledges of per≈øons Ecclefia≈øticall, in briefe of Ecclefia≈øticall liberty, all of them tending to the danger of the ≈øoules both of the Duke and of all the Senators, and al≈øo to the great ≈øcandall of many others. That they which had made the≈øe Lawes had incurred the Cen≈øures & the confi≈øcation of their fiefs, from which they could not be ab≈øolued but by the Pope, and by reuoking fir≈øt all the≈øe ≈øtatutes and ordinances, and by re≈øtoring all things into the former e≈øtate. But fora≈ømuch as the Duke and Senate after ≈øundry fatherly admonitions had not daigned to reuoke their Lawes, or to render the Pri≈øoners, he who might not in any ≈øort endure that Ecclefia≈øticall liberty and immunitie together with the authoritie of the See Apo≈øtolique ≈øhould be violated, following the example of ten of his predece≈ø≈øors there recited & many others, with the coun≈øell & con≈øent of the Cardinals, after mature deliberation, although the Decrees afore≈øaid were of them≈øelues void and of no value; neuerthele≈ø≈øe hee did now declare them to be ≈øuch. And further he did Excommunicate, declare & pronounce
for Excommunicated, as if they had beene particularly named, the Duke and the Senate which then were, and which ≈øhould be hereafter, together with all their fauourers, coun≈øellors, and adherents, if within the terme of foure and twentie daies, to be counted from the day of the publication (which he appointed in three termes, each of eight daies) the Duke and the Senate did not reuoke, abrogate, and di≈øannull the Decrees afore≈øaid, and all that which had followed thereupon, without any exception or excu≈øe; and if they cau≈øed not to be openly in all places publi≈øhed that abrogation of the Lawes, and the re≈øtitution of all that which had beene done in con≈øequence thereof, with promi≈øe not to doe any more ≈øuch acts for the time to come; and to giue account of all the≈øe things to him≈øelfe, as al≈øo actually render into the hands of his Nuntio the Canon and the Abbot: That from this Excommunication they could not be ab≈øolued but by the Pope, except it were in the point of death, in which ca≈øe if any one receiuing ab≈øolution ≈øhould afterwards recouer his health, he ≈øhould againe fall within this ≈øame Excommunication if he did not (≈øo farre as in him lay) obey this his commandement: That vntill they
had obeyed, he did forbid to bury any one decea≈øed in holy places. And if after the foure and twenty daies the Duke and Senate ≈øhould continue three daies longer ob≈øtinate, he put all their State vnder the Interdict, in ≈øuch ≈øort that none might celebrate Ma≈ø≈øes or Diuine Seruices, except in forme, in places and ca≈øes granted by common right. And he depriued the Duke and Senate of all their goods which they held of the Church of Rome, or of other Churches, as al≈øo of all their Priuiledges and indults obtained by it, and ≈øpecially of that priuiledge inabling them to proceed again≈øt Clarkes in certaine ca≈øes; re≈øeruing to Him≈øelfe and his Succe≈ø≈øors power to aggrauate and reaggrauate the Cen≈øures and penalties again≈øt them and again≈øt their adherents, fauourers, coun≈øellers & others, and to pa≈ø≈øe vnto other paines and remedies, if they per≈øi≈øted in their contempt, not with≈øtanding &c. Commanding all Patriarks, Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and other Ecclefia≈øtiques vnder penalty &c. re≈øpectiuely, that after they had receiued the≈øe letters, or had thereof notice, they ≈øhould publi≈øh them in their Churches, when their people were fully a≈ø≈øembled, and cau≈øe them to be affixed to the Church doores. Ordaining
that they ≈øhould giue credit vnto the Copies hereof, imprinted, being fir≈øt ≈øigned by a Notarie, and ≈øealed with the ≈øeale of ≈øome one promoted to Ecclefia≈øticall dignity. And that the publication made in Rome ≈øhould oblige as much and haue like force as if there had beene per≈øonall intimation.

div.head: SECOND BOOKE.
div.p:
THe publication of a Monitorie ≈øo rude, ≈øuddenly and vnexpectedly, thundered out again≈øt a State ≈øo great and pui≈ø≈øant, troubled the Mini≈øters of Princes which re≈øided with his Holine≈ø≈øe. The Marquis of Cha≈øtillon, Amba≈ø≈øador for the Emperour, (whether becau≈øe it ≈øeemed vnto him that the intere≈øts of his Ma≈øter did ≈øo require, or becau≈øe he had his owne e≈øtate confining vpon the Venetians,) made great in≈øtance with the Pope, to deferre a while; at which his Holine≈ø≈øe was little moued, either for that he e≈øteemed this Office of ≈ømall con≈øideration, as proceeding from a Mini≈øter, and not
from direction of his Ma≈øter, or becau≈øe hee lightly regarded the Emperour him≈øelfe, or his intere≈øts, as ≈øtanding in need of his aid in the war again≈øt the Turkes. For the≈øe rea≈øons, when≈øoeuer he iudged fit to communicate of this affaire with the Amba≈ø≈øadors, he neglected in a maner the Emperours. But the Marquis ≈øeeing how little account was made of his Office and interuention in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, ≈øent to the Emperour, to the end that he might haue order from him≈øelfe; which yet did no more ≈øucceed, by rea≈øon of the oppo≈øition made by the Mar≈øhall Prainer, ill affected towards the Venetians.

D'Alincourt, Amba≈ø≈øador of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, did the ≈øame Office, but as from him≈øelfe; to who≈øe demands the Pope would not conde≈øcend, but an≈øwered, that he ought rather to exhort the Republique to obey: wherefore he gaue adui≈øe to the King his Ma≈øter by the ordinary Currier, as well of that which had pa≈ø≈øed, as al≈øo of the Office by him tendered, and of the Popes an≈øwer. The Count of Verr√ºe, Amba≈ø≈øadour of the Duke of Sauoy, treated with more vigour in the name of his Ma≈øter with his Holine≈ø≈øe, exhorting him to make delay, and to find meanes to compo≈øe the≈øe differences: to whom he an≈øwered
that this were the ready way to render the Venetian, more ob≈øtinate, and that the Duke ought to addre≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe to them, to make them obey. In France, when vpon the thirtieth of Ianuary, Peter Prinli Amba≈ø≈øador of the Repub. gaue adui≈øe vnto the King of all that had pa≈ø≈øed, his Maiestie te≈øtified a very great de≈øire that there might bee found ≈øome meanes of agreement which might be without preiudice, and that a Treatie to this purpo≈øe might be furthered: giuing example in him≈øelfe, who had eluded the great in≈øtances which had beene made vnto him for the receiuing of the Trent Councell, ≈øo far as offer was made him to re≈øtraine it, where it ≈øhould be contrary to the liberties of the French Church. Now pre≈øently after the newes of the publication of the Monitory at Rome was arriued in France, the Nuntio Barberin made great in≈øtance, that the Amba≈ø≈øador of Venice might be excluded out of the Churches, but he could obtaine nothing; not only becau≈øe the purpo≈øe of the King was to carry him≈øelfe as a Neuter, but e≈øpecially becau≈øe that Kingdom holds it for a matter mo≈øt certaine and apparant, that Popes haue no power ouer the Temporalty of Princes, and that they

VpoÃÑ the≈øe rea≈øons, the Nuntio was coÃÑ≈øtrained to quit his preten≈øions, and they treated with the Amba≈ø≈øador of Venice after the maner accu≈øtomed, not altering any thing for the Popes Cen≈øures.
