To which propo≈øition the Senate hauing not ≈øpeedily an≈øwered, the Re≈øident returned to ≈øollicite them, offering that his Ma≈øter would come to Venice vnknowne and thence goe to Rome in po≈øte. But the Duke an≈øwered with thanks vnto the Duke of Mantua, adding the≈øe words; That they had done what was po≈ø≈øible; that the Republique was too much injured; that the things propo≈øed implied many contributies; that if any other thing ≈øhould happen to the Senate, they would impart it to him.

The great Duke at the ≈øame time ≈øaid vnto the Secretary of the Republique, that the French negotiation could not produce any effect, the Pope being much enraged; therefore it was meet to bend a little on both ≈øides, in as much as the Pope would hardly remoue the Interdict, if at Venice they did not giue him ≈øome cau≈øe to doe it; that for him≈øelfe he pre≈ø≈øed the affaire only in regard of the publique repo≈øe; that if he might be credited, he would interpo≈øe with hope yet with a≈ø≈øurance to reduce all to good termes, and that not for any intere≈øt, nor for ambition, being willing to leaue the glory thereof to others: that he had cau≈øed the ≈øame to be ≈øaid vnto the Pope: who thereupon had relea≈øed his rigour, euch with teares: that it was nece≈ø≈øary to re≈øolue to giue ≈øome ≈øatisfaction to his Holine≈ø≈øe, otherwi≈øe all would goe from bad to wor≈øe.

But on the contrary, Augu≈øtine Valerio, Cardinall and Bi≈øhop of Verona, a Prelate which in all his actions hath ≈øhewed a ≈øincere affection to his Countrey, with much deuotion to his Prince, writ after another fa≈øhion, ≈øaying; that he had ≈øpoke with the Pope, and that hee had found in him a good will and di≈øpo≈øition to ≈øome temperament: but that by the meanes of Princes
there was no hope to doe any good: he propo≈øed another cour≈øe, that the Patriarke elected ≈øhould goe to Rome as a priuate man, which would be acceptable to the Pope, who would ≈øee him willingly for diuers re≈øpects; that that Patriarke might treat to as good purpo≈øe and as effectually as an Amba≈ø≈øador.

In the Senate, after they had con≈øidered that which was propo≈øed froÃÑ ≈øo many hands, & examined the Rea≈øons which on the one ≈øide per≈øwaded to lend eare to ≈øome propo≈øitions, and to open a way to ≈øome treaty, by yeelding ≈øomewhat to content the Pope; and on the other, tho≈øe which forced them to pre≈øerue their Libertie, neuer till then violated, euen in mo≈øt difficult times; they re≈øolued to an≈øwer all on the ≈øame fa≈øhion.

To the Refident of Mantua, after they had affectionately thanked his Highne≈ø≈øe for his good: will and diligence, it was ≈øaid, that the de≈øires of the Republique were greatly bent on peace; but hauing beene grieuou≈øly offended by the Pope, it was not meet they ≈øhould fir≈øt moue for a reconciliation; that when≈øoeuer the Pope ≈øhould repaire the iniuries which dured yet with the Cen≈øures, they would ≈øtudie to giue him any
contentment which might not preiudice their E≈øtate: that the Senate hoped the Duke in his wi≈ødome would acknowledge that the conditions propo≈øed were to their damage, and would approue their deliberation, as knowing how important it was to be iealous of the publique Libertie.

To Moun≈øieur de Fre≈øne they an≈øwered to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; that notwith≈øtanding the great iniuries of the Pope, and the euill will which he caried to the Republique, neuerthele≈ø≈øe they were ready to receiue any iu≈øt aduice tending to peace. And therefore that he ≈øhould imploy him≈øelfe toward the Pope, to cau≈øe him to take off his Cen≈øures, that ≈øo a way might be opened for the Senate to ≈øhew their good will; and then in re≈øpect vnto his Maie≈øtie they would doe what≈øoeuer they could po≈ø≈øibly, ≈øauing alwaies their Libertie.

The Amba≈ø≈øadour hereupon replied; that the King fore≈øeeing and fearing the euils which would follow vpon the≈øe differences, not for any particular intere≈øt, but meerely out of re≈øpect to the Republique, had deliberated to interpo≈øe Him≈øelfe; that alreadie at Rome he had done all that could be de≈øired in this affaire. Wherefore,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
it ≈øeemed vnto him that the Senate ought to put confidence in the King, and declare vnto him what they would doe, in ca≈øe that the Pope ≈øhould take off the Cen≈øures, or for to induce him to reuoke his Monitory. But ≈øince the Senate would not depart from the≈øe general termes, nor tru≈øt the King, hee was re≈øolued to retire him≈øelfe, and henceforth not to trouble any per≈øon about this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. For touching the Pope, who beleeued that he had not done ami≈ø≈øe, as being ruled and conducted by the holy Spirit, and that in reuoking his Cen≈øures he ≈øhould ≈øuffer in his reputation, it could not be po≈ø≈øible to draw him to it, but only by ≈øhewing him what he might obtaine for his ≈øatisfaction in fauour of his Dignitie. He ≈øaid moreouer, that Alincourt found the Pope of a nature firme and re≈øolute, and that it was meet to be a skilfull Orator to per≈øwade him; that if ≈øometimes being vanqui≈øhed by rea≈øon hee yeelded a little, yet after he was wont to re≈øume his former re≈øolution. And when he was forced by rea≈øon, he would ≈øay, he would thinke on the matter: but this thinking was to remaine con≈øtant in his re≈øolutions. Wherefore, if they would ≈øay no more, the King his Ma≈øter would not intermeddle.

div.head: THIRD BOOKE.
div.p:
WHile≈øt the≈øe things were treated at Venice, at Rome, and in the Courts of Princes, the Ie≈øuites did not cea≈øe to doe all ≈øorts of euill offices to the Republique within and without Italy, in the Cities where they liued; ≈øcattering many calumnies, as well in priuate Di≈øcour≈øes, as in their publique Sermons. So farre, as that they ≈øent Letters into the Signiory to their adherents, and cau≈øed their Deuotes to come to the Confines, and them≈øelues very often entred the State di≈øgui≈øed and vnknowne, for to ≈øeduce the Subiects: publi≈øhing Indulgences in fauour of them who would ob≈øerue the Interdict, or per≈øwade others to ob≈øerue it, or who would fauour the preten≈øions of the Pope. They forged al≈øo fal≈øe and counterfeit Letters, di≈øper≈øing them vnder the name of the Republique of Genoa, to that of Venice; and al≈øo ≈øcattered in many places a writing of one of their Sectaries in the name of the Citie of Verona, to the Citie of Bre≈ø≈øe. The≈øe
artifices being come to the knowledge of the Senate, it was decreed that information ≈øhould be made again≈øt the ≈øeditious actions of the≈øe men, as well ≈øince the≈øe la≈øt occa≈øions, as long time before vpon many others. And touching that which they had done in this la≈øt occa≈øion, it was manife≈øtly iu≈øtified, that in their Sermons they had v≈øed inuectiues again≈øt the Republique, calling them Heretiques, Lutherans, and ≈ølandering the Gouernment as tyrannicall, abominable, with an infinite number of like Epithetes, and that within the Cities of Ferrara, Bologne, Parma, Mantua, Bari, Palermo, and in other places: that from their ≈øleights and ≈øugge≈øtions had proceeded all the euill pa≈ø≈øages happening in Spaine and in Bohemia vnto the Amba≈ø≈øadour of the Republique, and in France and Polonia they had attempted that they might receiue all kinds of affronts: e≈øpecially in England that they had done all the di≈øgrace vnto them which they could with the Catholiques of that Kingdome, ≈øo farre as to finde fault that the Republique held an Amba≈ø≈øador with the King, as that King reciprocally at Venice, although they excu≈øed other Princes, ≈øaying, that their intere≈øts required it, but there was not the like rea≈øon for the Republique.
That with the Princes of Italy they had endeuoured to effect that the Republique ≈øhould not be permitted to make any leuy of men within their E≈øtates; & when this deuice ≈øucceeded not, they went in all places dete≈øting the name of Venice, and finally menacing them that ≈øhould go to warre in their defence; the ≈øeditions are numberle≈ø≈øe which they haue excited within the Dominions of the State by their Letters, in≈øtructions, and ≈øpeeches with the Subiects of the Republique, who went for their affaires vnto the Cities where the≈øe men were, & with their deuoted ones which they cau≈øed to come vpon the confines of the State. It was further iu≈øtified, that a good part of the vexations done by the Pope vnto the Republique, vpon the≈øe occa≈øions had proceeded from their in≈øtigations, and from the hopes that they had giuen him, that they had a faction, and could put diui≈øion in the Senate. Now for matters pa≈ø≈øed formerly, it was al≈øo verified, that when the Republique after the death of Henry 3. gaue the title of mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King vnto Henry 4. the≈øe men had vaunted at Rome that they had put ≈øcruples in the con≈øciences of many Senators, who had repented them≈øelues of that they had done, promi≈øing to ab≈øolue
them in ca≈øe that they would promi≈øe to retract; that therefore it was facile at the lea≈øt in≈øtance of the Pope, to change the whole face of this affaire, which was the cau≈øe that his Holine≈ø≈øe pre≈ø≈øed them, who being not ≈øatisfied, hence followed ≈øo many di≈øcontentments; that on diuers occa≈øions they had ≈øhewed them≈øelues the fauourers of great Princes, & by that meanes had mingled them≈øelues in the affaires of Gouernment; that they di≈øpended yearely aboue an hundred crownes in the portage of Letters, whereby appeared the multitude of their affaires, and the corre≈øpondencies which they had in all parts. Further, it was proued again≈øt them that they had great de≈øignes vpon the goods and faculties of their Penitents, and of Women e≈øpecially, to the great preiudice of Families. Al≈øo their Doctrine was con≈øidered in matters Politique; that they prai≈øed Monarchy, and blamed an Ari≈øtocratie, with certaine Maximes very contrary to the Gouernment and In≈øtitution of the Republique: adde hereunto that the Ie≈øuites had beene the Authors and In≈øtruments of all Vproares, Seditions, Confu≈øions, and Ruines happening within our Times in all Kingdomes and States in the world. Wherfore hauing found
their faults in ≈øo great number, and they not only in ≈øome particulars of them, but in the corps of their Societie; all was propo≈øed in Senate, who deliberated hereupon the fourteenth of Iune, and made the Decree which followeth; That the Congregation of Ie≈øuites hauing beene receiued at Venice from their fir≈øt beginning, and there euer ≈øince fauoured, they on the contrary returning nothing but ingratitude towards the Republique, and ≈øhewing them≈øelues ≈øtill inclined to doe all ≈øorts of euill Offices to that State: in which di≈øpo≈øition they yet continued by in≈øupportable enterpri≈øes, and in≈øolent calumnies, ≈øeeking all occa≈øions to offend them: For the≈øe cau≈øes, they ≈øhould neuer be admitted or receiued in any place of the State, nor this Decree reuoked, vnle≈ø≈øe the whole Proce≈ø≈øe again≈øt them were fir≈øt read in full Senate, (which con≈øi≈øts of no le≈ø≈øe than 180. Senators,) whereof fiue parts (the whole being compo≈øed of ≈øix) ≈øhould giue ≈øuffrage for their reuocation. And this may be one certain argument of their enormous and euident crimes, that there was not any one Per≈øon (of ≈øo great a number) who ≈øpake anything in fauour of them: and in the Scrutiny made by ≈øecret voices, all were found vnanimous to
decree their perpetuall bani≈øhment; notwith≈øtanding that ≈øome of this number had formerly v≈øed them as their Confe≈ø≈øors, who had much fauoured them on many other occa≈øions.

But the Pope fore-≈øeeing the difficulties to come to this accord ≈øo much de≈øired, with the honour which he expected; and likewi≈øe con≈øidering that all the ≈øhifts and artifices as well of the Ie≈øuites as of other Eccle≈øiastiques, could not cau≈øe any trouble in the State of the Republique, (which he thought might be greatly profitable to induce the Senate to yeeld to his will) all enterpri≈øes to this effect re≈øting vaine and without fruit, as al≈øo being not able by ≈øo many deuices and trickes to draw to him≈øelfe any other than ≈øome ≈øimple per≈øons, adui≈øed him≈øelfe of a mo≈øt ≈øubtill inuention: Which was, that on the nineteenth of Iune he publi≈øhed a Iubilee, whereby he inuited all Chri≈øtians to pray God with him for the nece≈ø≈øities of the Church; and to this end granted Indulgences, Ab≈øolutions, and Remi≈ø≈øions to all, excepting them that were found in Cities or places Interdicted, whom hee excluded from the≈øe fauours, not comprehending them ≈øo much as in their number, who≈øe prayers he implored. In Italy no Spirituall thing is more
wi≈øhed or expected by the people, and when it is granted, nothing receiued with more deuout affection than a Iubilee. Whereupon at Rome they beleeued that the people within the State of Venice ≈øeeing them≈øelues depriued of ≈øuch Graces giuen to all the faithfull, would certainly be moued with ≈øedition to ≈øeeke their part in them. But the euill de≈øigne which the Ie≈øuites did hope would ≈øucceed by their Sermons in the neighbouring places, where they had publiquely declamed again≈øt the Honour of the Republique, being fru≈øtrate; they adui≈øed hereupon to put in worke their la≈øt artifice to rai≈øe vp commotions, by writing to their Adherents, that although the Pope had excluded from the Iubilee in generall all the Subiects of the State of Venice, yet they had power from his Holine≈ø≈øe to grant it to ≈øuch per≈øons as would ob≈øerue the conditions by them propounded, among which the≈øe were ≈øome, not to goe to Ma≈ø≈øe, not to approue the publique rea≈øons and actions, and others more important.

The end of this Inbilee was very well knowne in Spaine, for although they haue a very great deuotion towards the Indulgences which come from Rome, and principally in the Iubilees, neuerthele≈ø≈øe
they remained in ≈øu≈øpence; and though the Nuntio were very in≈øtant to cau≈øe it to be publi≈øhed, yet three Moneths pa≈ø≈øed before they gaue their con≈øent.

In this ≈øame time wherein at Rome they were thus bu≈øied in Ceremonies, a certaine Writing was affixed at Vicenza, and many other places, whereby the Republique was exhorted to withdraw it ≈øelfe from the obedience of the Romane Church, and hereupon it touched many points of Religion, calling the Pope Antichri≈øt: Which being knowne at Venice, the Senate was there with greatly troubled, their re≈øolution being to continue alwayes mo≈øt con≈øtant to con≈øerue their Religion inuiolable. They con≈øidered that how≈øoeuer ≈øuch actions might be done by ≈øtealth, and ≈øome one man, neuerthele≈ø≈øe if proui≈øion were not made ≈øtrictly to deterre any more to imitate the like, there might follow very pernicious con≈øequences. Whereupon they cau≈øed to bee publi≈øhed a very rigorous Ban, promi≈øing recompence to him that could di≈øcouer the Author, giuing charge to the Gouernours to make an exact ≈øearch after him. But with all the diligence which they could v≈øe nothing could be fouÃÑd, ≈øaue only ≈øome ob≈øcure coÃÑiectures that this
was an Artifice of the Ecclefia≈øtiques them≈øelues, whether to ≈øhew the danger wherein they were, and thereby to incite the State to ≈øome ≈øpeedie accord with the Pope, or for to verifie the calumnies which the Ie≈øuiticall Fathers di≈øper≈øed again≈øt the Republique.

At the ≈øame time when the Pope publi≈øhed this Iubilee, he wrought in ≈øuch ≈øort with the Marquis de Villena, that he di≈øpatched a Currier into Spaine, to giue adui≈øe vnto his King, that his Holine≈ø≈øe would ca≈øt him≈øelfe intirely vnder his Protection; and that for this rea≈øon he demanded not onely his fauour, but ≈øome ≈øuccour of men. But the King of Spaine an≈øwered his Amba≈ø≈øador, that he ought to repre≈ø≈øe the≈øe thoughts, in as much as the troubles of Italy would not be aduantageous either to the See Apo≈øtolique, or the Crowne of Spaine. And although this an≈øwer afflicted the Pope beyond mea≈øure, neuerthele≈ø≈øe to trie all meanes, he him≈øelfe di≈øpatched a Po≈øt with a Breue to that King, and a Writing containing his Rea≈øons: which he accompanied with a Letter addre≈ø≈øed to the Duke of Lerm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
wherein with an ardent affection he recommended vnto him his Per≈øon and Affaires, with offers of Obligation and acknowledgment,
calling him the Ba≈øe of the Crowne of Spaine; vpon whom depended the Catholique Monarchie, and the onely pillar of the Church.

This Breue was written fir≈øt in Latine, but afterwards in the vulgar Italian, for to giue vnto him the title of Excellence, a thing which the Popes haue not v≈øed. Notwith≈øtanding all this, the Pope, di≈øtru≈øting to obtaine from Spaine that which he de≈øired, hearkned vnto the treaties of peace propo≈øed. And it is certaine, that the offices done by the Cardinals and Amba≈ø≈øadors at Rome, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the Amba≈ø≈øador of France, had ≈øuch effect, that being ioyned with the remor≈øe which the Pope felt in his con≈øcience, they reduced him to ≈øuch a point that he was neere per≈øwaded to conde≈øcent to a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of the Cen≈øures, to open a way to ≈øome farther treaty; and he came ≈øo far as to collect hereupon the ≈øuffrages and opinions of the Cardinals. But while≈øt he was con≈øidering of their aduice, in the beginning of Iuly, at the ≈øame time when Fre≈øne made his la≈øt in≈øtance whereof we haue ≈øpoken, and when the Ban again≈øt the Ie≈øuites, and the publication of a Iubilee interrupted the treaty, came the an≈øwer of the King of Spaine to the Letters of his Holine≈ø≈øe:
Which was pre≈øented vnto him by the Marquis de Villena, being accompanied with three Cardinals; which imported, That the King had de≈øired that the differences with the Repub. of Venice ≈øhould not haue come ≈øo far; but becau≈øe He ≈øaw the honour of his Holine≈ø≈øe much intere≈ø≈øed, he was re≈øolued to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him with his forces; which his intention he had ≈øignified to his Mini≈øters in Italie, and likewi≈øe giuen order that they ≈øhould make it knowne to the Princes his Dependents.

This Letter was read by the Pope with great ioy, which he te≈øtified not onely by words, but by his Letters full of affection to that King, and to the Duke of Lerma, which he ≈øent by an expre≈ø≈øe Currier. There were who beleeued that the≈øe Letters, which were ≈øaid to come from Spaine, had beene written in Italy: and they alledged for a good coniecture, that the King therein wrote that he had ≈øignified his plea≈øure to the Amba≈ø≈øador of Venice who was with him, although he had not ≈øpoken one word to him thereof before he had receiued the an≈øwer of the Pope. But it is true that the Duke of Lerma for the honour which his Holine≈ø≈øe had done him, and in regard of his humble praiers in his
Letters, was willing on his ≈øide to corre≈øpond, which was to him very ea≈øie: For the Coun≈øellors of E≈øtate, by rea≈øon of the tran≈ølation of the Court, hauing permi≈ø≈øion to ab≈øent them≈øelues for three Moneths, none of them were at the Court, ≈øaue the Duke de Chin√ßon, who (as brother in law to the Marquis de Villena) had the ≈øame de≈øignes. It was further ≈øaid by ≈øome Mini≈øters of that King in Italy, that he ≈øuffered him≈øelfe to be per≈øwaded to write that Letter, vpon hope to pacifie things more ea≈øily, ina≈ømuch as ≈øome Venetian Prelates had a≈ø≈øured, that when the King of Spaine ≈øhould declare him≈øelfe openly for the Pope, the Senate would yeeld, and quickly humble them≈øelues: which being writ from Rome into Spaine, did render the demand of his Holine≈ø≈øe more ea≈øie with the King and the Duke of Lerma, both which inclined to the con≈øeruation of the peace.

But the Amba≈ø≈øador of the King of Spaine at Rome, and his Mini≈øters in Italy, pretended by this Letter & other offices, to haue put the See Apo≈øtolique in great reputation: ≈øo that Amba≈ø≈øador ≈øaid vnto the Pope; That his King would make him obtaine with a few words that which others could not doe with many; and that hee
would bring the Venetians pro≈øtrate at the feet of his Holine≈ø≈øe. Hereby it ≈øeemed vnto the Spaniards that they had well merited of the Holy See, and that they might expect requitall from the Pope, at their need. And therefore purpo≈øing hereby to reape no le≈ø≈øe profit and reputation than the Pope him≈øelfe, they required of him three things: The fir≈øt that he would make at Rome a publique Fe≈øtiuall, with bonefires and other ≈øignes of ioy and gratulation. The ≈øecond, that the Letter might be read in Con≈øi≈øtory and con≈øerued within the Archiues. The third, that he would totally breake off the treaty begun by the Amba≈ø≈øador of France, and not ≈øpeake any more of this affaire with the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King. Which demands being publi≈øhed in Court, and from thence thorowout the Citie, moued Alincourt to goe to the Audience, and to giue the Pope to vnder≈øtand what rumors were ≈øcattered of the Triumphs which were made by occa≈øion of this Letter, and of the things promi≈øed and demanded by the Amba≈øs. of Spaine. To which he added, that all was nothing but vaine o≈øtentation, to interrupt the treaty of Peace, and to hold in di≈øcord two of the greate≈øt Princes in Italy, who remaining vnited
might be a counterpoi≈øe ≈øufficient to hinder the de≈øignes of the≈øe men: that the termes which they v≈øed were too too arrogant, euen in the mouth of a Monarch of all the world: that the Spaniards knew well enough them≈øelues and their feeblene≈ø≈øe, which they could not otherwi≈øe maintaine: that in Italy they beleeued they might command all, and be the ≈øole arbritrators of all things; neuerthele≈ø≈øe if they would be ≈øtirring, others would not onely looke on with the armes acro≈ø≈øe, and let them doe what they li≈øt. The Pope confe≈ø≈øed that the demands of the Spaniards were true, but that they could not plea≈øe him, and that Hee could doe nothing therein: that he would not cea≈øe for all that to continue the Treaty already begun: True it is, that he held him≈øelfe obliged to the two Crownes for the piety of the two Kings, from whom hee equally hoped for all protection: That he had already taken the voices of the Cardinals, and that euery of them coun≈øelled him not to pa≈ø≈øe further on the points propo≈øed for accord, if the Venetians did not ≈øhew re≈øpect. Notwith≈øtanding, the partizans of Spaine did not cea≈øe to extoll and magnifie the offers of that King, ≈øo far, that the Cardinals
of the Congregation con≈øulting what was to be done to reduce the Venetians to yeeld to the will of the Pope, concluded and reported to his Holine≈ø≈øe, that the ≈øuccours of the Catholique King would be more than ≈øufficient, and would not faile him, prouided that he would yeeld him that which be de≈øired touching Sicilie; which (as men beleeued) they ≈øaid, after they had talked and agreed with the Marquis de Villena, the Catholique Amba≈ø≈øador.

In Spaine the Coun≈øellors ≈øpake on the ≈øame fa≈øhion to the Nuntio, ≈øaying, that if the Pope de≈øired fauour of their King, it was but rea≈øon that he ≈øhould yeeld ≈øomewhat on his ≈øide, for to giue ≈øome ≈øatisfaction vnto his ≈øubiects, to the end they might not repent them≈øelues to haue beene embarqued in ≈øuch a warre. They touched in a word the remitting of the fief o Naples, the granting of Ferrara for the garri≈øons of their ≈øouldiers, and Ancona for the retrait of their Armie. The Count de Fuentes in the meane while in execution of the promi≈øes of his Ma≈øter, ≈øent Don Francis de Mendozza, Captaine of the Ca≈øtle of Lodi, the Gouernour of Lech, and the Captaine Lachiuga to the Princes of Italy; diuiding among them the charge according

The Duke ≈øaid, That for the repo≈øe of Italy, and to hinder ≈øo many mi≈øchiefes as might follow vpon the warre if it were begun, if the Catholique King were certaine, that the Pope being moued on this fa≈øhion

The ≈øame day the Amba≈ø≈øador of France was at the Audience, where he reported, how the Pope had ≈øaid to Moun≈øieur de Alincourt, that he had taken the voices of all the Cardinals, which were found all conformable, and that according to their aduice he could not come to a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of the Cen≈øures, if in behalfe of the Republique

The Senate adui≈øed their Amba≈ø≈øador in Spaine of all the≈øe propo≈øitions and an≈øwers, commanding him to thanke the Catholique King for his offer to interpo≈øe in this affaire, and to make remon≈øtrance vnto him, how needfull it was for that Crowne to con≈øerue the amitie of the Republique, and ≈øo mode≈øtly to complaine that the de≈øignes of the Pope were fomented by the Letters of his Maie≈øtie, and by the offices of ≈øome of his Mini≈øters. The Amba≈ø≈øadour of England at Venice ≈øpake on the ≈øame manner, ≈øaying, That he had particular Commandement from the King his Ma≈øter, to oblige him vnder the Word of a King, to a neere Vnion with the Republique, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them with Conn≈øell and Forces, as al≈øo to labour with

The Amba≈ø≈øador hereunto added, that he had order from the King to publi≈øh or to keepe ≈øecret this Declaration, according as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme mo≈øt expedient to the Republique. The King was thanked in the Per≈øon of his Amba≈ø≈øadour with many words, as al≈øo Iu≈øtinian their Amba≈ø≈øadour with his Maiestie had charge to doe the ≈øame; and further, a Letter was written vnto that King, with ≈øuch thankfulne≈ø≈øe as was meet.

The Amba≈ø≈øadour of France a few dayes after that the An≈øwer of his King was arriued, and haply to ≈øweeten it, came to the Audience, where he made a long Di≈øcour≈øe for the Accord, concluding that though it ≈øhould not fall out, yet
the King would not depart from the Amity which he had with the Republique. That therefore his Maie≈øtie de≈øired to be throughly informed of their Rea≈øons, not only for the merit and iu≈øtice of the Lawes, and other things controuerted, but al≈øo touching the order which they had holden in oppo≈øing the Cen≈øures of the Pope, who complained not only of the things afore≈øaid, but that he had receiued ≈øome new offences, both for hindring Nauigation into places of the Church, and for bani≈øhing vtterly out of their E≈øtate the Order of the Ie≈øuites. To which by decree of Senate was made an≈øwer, thanking the King for his good and ≈øincere affection, and al≈øo there was giuen in writing to the Amba≈ø≈øador, a briefe Summary of their Rea≈øons, for iu≈øtification as well of the Lawes and of the Iudgement, as of that which the Senate and the other Magi≈øtrates had done to repul≈øe the iniuries of the Pope, and to hinder the Seditions which the Cen≈øures might haue occa≈øioned. The coÃÑplaint touching Nauigation was al≈øo re≈øolued, ≈øaying that it appertained to euery good GouernmeÃÑt, to prouide that the State might be furni≈øhed with things nece≈ø≈øary, not letting that be caried away to others, whereof it ≈øelfe ≈øtands in need; that accordingly
the Republique had ≈øtayed all Ve≈ø≈øels at Sea, wherein were proui≈øions nece≈ø≈øary for the State; whereupon, if it followed that the State Eccle≈øia≈øticall were in ≈øome want, this was not their fault, but the order of humane things ≈øo required. Concerning the Ie≈øuites, that they had not beene bani≈øhed, but rather were gone away of them≈øelues, as not being willing to obey the Commandement giuen vnto them, to continue the Diuine Seruice; but after their departure hauing notice of an infinite number of iniuries, Machinations, and Trea≈øons by them contriued, the Senate had ordained (as Iu≈øtice required) that they ≈øhould neuer more returne. But although the King had promi≈øed to continue his ≈øincere Amity with the Republique, yet he would neuer employ him≈øelfe in any particular thing which might aid their Cau≈øe; on the contrary, when their Amba≈ø≈øador reque≈øted his Maie≈øtie to hinder the leuy of Sui≈ø≈øes, which the Pope purpo≈øed to make, and to fauour the leuy of the Republique; he did refu≈øe, ≈øaying, it was a meanes to make him declare him≈øelfe, which he intended not to doe, but ≈øhewing him≈øelfe neutrall to treat the Agreement; ≈øaying be≈øides that it was needle≈ø≈øe for the Republique to make ≈øo great
proui≈øion of Armes, it being ≈øufficient to haue their owne Places well furni≈øhed.

div.head: FOVRTH BOOKE.
div.p:
WHile≈øt the≈øe things were thus in treaty, the Spaniards attempted to imbroile the Republique with the Turke, to the end they might be con≈øtrained to haue recour≈øe to them, and ≈øo they might haue power to carry the Senate to accept of a Compo≈øition with the Pope vpon ≈øuch termes as plea≈øed them. But their Proiect was ≈øo farre from ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, that on the contrary there had falne vpon them a great mi≈øchiefe, if by the prudence of the Senate it had not beene diuerted. The occa≈øion was this. The Marquis de Santa Croce, being departed from Naples (after he had receiued Benediction from the Nuntio,) with ≈øix and twentie Gallies, he pa≈ø≈øed to Me≈øsina, where he ≈øtrengthened him≈øelfe with fourteene more; and hauing aduice that the Venetian Armie was at Corfu, hee ≈øailed very ≈øecretly, ≈øtriking his Ma≈øts that he might not be
di≈øcouered; and in this fa≈øhion he arriued the tenth of Augu≈øt at Durazzo, a Citie of Albany (holden by the Turkes,) which he finding neare void of Inhabitants, who were occupied at their Harue≈øt, as He him≈øelfe hath reported in his Printed Relation, he ≈øacked and burned it with little re≈øi≈øtance, carrying away 155. men, women and children, among whom were thirty Chri≈øtians, which he ≈øet free as ≈øoone as he came to Otranto: he tooke al≈øo thirty peeces of Ordnance, the ≈ømalle≈øt he carryed away, being con≈øtrained to leaue the greater cloyed, for feare of the Turkes, who came with Forces vnto the re≈øcue. This newes being come to Venice, greatly di≈øplea≈øed the Senate, who feared that the Turks would reuenge them≈øelues by falling vpoÃÑ their State, which was neare≈øt vnto them, as at other times they had done; or that at lea≈øt they would enter the Gulfe, and ≈øet vpon Puglia, and by this meanes put things in a confu≈øion. Wherefore the Amba≈ø≈øador of Spaine was called, and the Duke greatly complained vnto him, ≈øaying, That for a trifle they would prouoke the Turks, and draw their Armies into the Gulfe, with no le≈ø≈øe damage to his Ma≈øter, than to the Republique; and that the decea≈øed King, who≈øe prudence was
≈øuch that it merited to be imitated, would neuer con≈øent to ≈øuch enterpri≈øes. The Duke further intimated, that if hereafter they ≈øhould make ≈øuch attempts, they would not be indured. To which the Amba≈ø≈øadour an≈øwered, that he had prayed the King his Ma≈øter to command that his Armies ≈øhould not henceforth enter within the Gulfe.

But at Con≈øtantinople, the Turkes perceiued very well the Artifices of Spaine, and that the enterpri≈øe of Durazzo had beene attempted to no other end, than to ≈øet them at ods with the Republique. And therefore the Grand Seigneur ≈øent command to the Captaine of his Army to keepe good vnion and intelligence with the Venetian Armies, to the damage of the Pope & Spaniards. Afterward, the fir≈øt Vi≈øier called Octauian Bon, Bayliefe of the Republique, and complained of the a≈ø≈øault made on Durazzo, concluding that the Republike was obliged to be ≈øen≈øible of it; becau≈øe the Grand Seigneur knew very well that it was done onely to ≈øet him at variance with them: but on the contrary, being willing to proceed generou≈øly, on this occa≈øion they ≈øhould be freed both from this and ≈øome other troubles on their ≈øide, implying hereby the V ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hocs with
diuers other damages and di≈øplea≈øures, v≈øing withall that Prouerbe of the Turkes, It is better to be one day a Cocke, than alwayes a Hen. He offered him to ioyne with them his pre≈øent Army, with all ≈øorts of aid again≈øt the Spaniards and the Pope, ≈øhewing vnto him that the Republique had no greater enemies than Spaniards and Prie≈øts: which being manife≈øt, they ought to thinke of reuenge, and re≈øt a≈ø≈øured alwayes of their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, it being a vaine thing to arme, and not to v≈øe their Armes again≈øt their enemies. And if they thought not fit to vnite with their Armies and other ≈øuccours, he propo≈øed that if the Venetian Army would a≈ø≈øault the State of the Church, or of the Spaniard on the one ≈øide, they would doe it on the other: and that the Grand Seigneur had writ to all his Mini≈øters to lend all ≈øorts of aid to the Republique, without expecting any further order from the Port.

A few dayes after, the Army of the Turkes appeared in the Gomenices, not farre from Corfu, to the number of 55. Gallics, commanded by Iaphar Ba≈øhaw; to whom the Generall Pa≈øqualigo, who was then at Corfu, and commanded the Venetian Army, hauing ≈øent Victor Barbaro his Secretary for to vi≈øit Him, and to complaine of
≈øome ≈ømall damages done by ≈øome Galeots of Cor≈øares, Iapher ≈øpeedily di≈øpatched twenty Gallies to take them, which accordingly they did, and hanged the Captaine. The Ba≈øhaw further di≈øcour≈øed vnto the Secretary of the great e≈øteeme which the Grand Seignieur made of the Republique. To which he adioyned, that he had commandement from his Ma≈øter, by his Letters of the fifth of September, to ioyne him≈øelfe with the Venetian Forces, to goe again≈øt the Pope and the King of Spaine, in ≈øuch manner as he ≈øhould be adui≈øed by the Venetian Captaines, or el≈øe to march ≈øeuerally if they ≈øhould iudge it better. And the Ba≈øhaw ≈øent three of his Gallies to the Generall Pa≈øqualigo, with the Bei of Damita, him of Scio, and of A≈ø≈øan, Surnamed Ianarin, a Genoan by Nation, for to giue him account of the Order which he had from Con≈øtantinople, and thereupon to ≈øollicite his re≈øolution. To this Office the Generall of the Venetians corre≈øponded, prai≈øing and thanking the Grand Seignieur; yet he added that it was meet to giue aduice of this Propo≈øition at Venice, and from thence to expect a re≈øolution. The Turkes offered a light Galley to performe the Voyage more ≈øpeedily, the returne
whereof they would expect. But the Generall alledging the length of time, and the incommodity which the Armie might ≈øuffer, if it remained ≈øo many dayes at Sea, wrought in ≈øuch ≈øort that they retired, giuing them to vnder≈øtand that they ≈øhould be aduerti≈øed what re≈øolution was taken.

In this Moneth of August was begunne a kinde of Warre by Writing, offen≈øiue on the Popes part, and defen≈øiue on the ≈øide of the Republique, handled on both parts with very much heat, and which ≈øerued greatly to the Negotiation which was in treating. For though it was certaine, that the Pope was the fir≈øt that a≈ø≈øailed the Republique with this ≈øort of Weapons, neuerthele≈ø≈øe, he was ≈øo farre infeiour in the euent, that this was one of the principall Cau≈øes which incited him to an Agreement, and he ≈øuffered more in his reputation by the≈øe Writings, then the Republique, by the continuation of the Cen≈øures.

The beginning and progre≈ø≈øe hereof was thus. After that the Republique had hindered the execution of the Cen≈øures, by ≈øuch rea≈øons, ≈øuch dexteritie and con≈øtancie, as before wee haue mentioned, the Pope, who ≈øaw him≈øelfe
blamed by the Court of Rome for his incon≈øiderate proceedings in this affaire, trauelled on his ≈øide to finde ≈øome Rea≈øons, and commanded Some to ≈øtudie the≈øe matters: then in the end re≈øolued to publi≈øh his Motiues, and cau≈øed a Writing to be framed by Scipio Gobellucci (to whom he gaue for recompence the Office of a Secretarie, which he was wont to ≈øell,) which Writing he ≈øent to Mantua, Milan, Cremona, and Ferrara, to the end that it might be di≈øper≈øed in all Quarters. He ≈øent it likewi≈øe into Spaine to his Nuntio, not only for his In≈øtruction, but al≈øo that it might be diuulged. Hereupon at Venice ≈øome propo≈øed that it was nece≈ø≈øarie to publi≈øh in like ≈øort the Rea≈øons of the Repub. as well to oppo≈øe the fore≈øaid Writing, as becau≈øe it was a thing earne≈øtly de≈øired by the Subiects; and ≈øo much the more, for that hauing in their Letters of the 6. of May, ≈øpoken of the nullitie of the Monitorie, it ≈øeemed requi≈øite that the Rea≈øons thereof ≈øhould bee explained and declared, and how the Letters of the Duke were ≈øupported by good and cleare arguments. And that which incited them yet more, was an aduice that the Ie≈øuites, no le≈ø≈øe pa≈ø≈øionate in this affaire then the Pope him≈øelfe, went vp and
downe ≈øaying, per≈øwading, and declaiming in their Chaires and al≈øo writ vnto their adherents within the State, that if the Republique had any Rea≈øons they would haue manife≈øted them: but that it ≈øufficed them in generall to ≈øay they had many Rea≈øons, being not able to particularize in any. Others ≈øaid that they had done enough for a ≈øufficient defence, and that it was not meet to ≈øay any more till they were forced: and this adui≈øe preuailed, for the great reuerence which the Republique carried to the See Apo≈øtolique: thinking it more fit to faile in ≈øome point of reputation, then to giue any ≈øigne of di≈øre≈øpect vnto that See, although they had receiued from it ≈øo manife≈øt iniuries. Yet it was not po≈ø≈øible to retaine ≈øome liuely wits, that they ≈øhould not write ≈øomewhat by ≈øtealth; hence there came abroad diuers Di≈øcour≈øes on both ≈øides, but yet onely in hand-writing. Diuers Letters were al≈øo written vnder fained Names to gaine the more credit, and in particular, one in the Name of the Senate vnto the Cities their Subiects. It is true (as hath beene ≈øaid) that there was one written and read in all the Coun≈øels of Cities, but not any Copies thereof were giuen to any. It may be that ≈øome per≈øon of learning hauing
heard it read, and committing it (as he thought) to memorie, did afterwards ≈øet downe in Writing rather that which he imagined he had heard then that which he heard indeed; or el≈øe, thinking the ≈øtile of the Senate too mode≈øt, too re≈øerued and reuerent, he adioyned thereunto of his owne ≈øome biting and eager words to fit it better to the ta≈øte of the vulgar, and ≈øo let it runne vnder hand among the People. But at Milan there fell out an accident of mo≈øt pernicious con≈øequence, where ≈øome Ecclefia≈øtiques of great qualitie cau≈øed to imprint (without the name of the Author or of the Place) a Writing of one ≈øheet of paper very ≈øeditious, wherein was affirmed, again≈øt all ≈øound doctrine, that Mariages within the State of the Republique were inualide, the Matrimoniall coniunction Adultery, and the Children all Ba≈øtards; that it was not onely lawfull, but euen meritorious, for Pa≈øtors to abandon their Flockes. And to conceale the Place where this was printed, they forbade the Printer very ≈øtraitly, euen vnder paine of Cen≈øures, that he ≈øhould not giue any one Copie thereof within Milan. The ≈øheet was therefore di≈øtributed in the Confines of Bergamo, Bre≈øcia and Crema. To contradict this Writing,
a certaine Per≈øon publi≈øhed ≈øome Treati≈øes written 150. yeeres agoe by Iohn Ger≈øon, ≈øo well fitted to the affaires of this time that they ≈øeem'd to be written on this occa≈øion, and ≈øuch as certainely at this day none could write ≈øo well and ≈øo re≈øolutely. Hereunto was adioyned a Letter, without the name of the Author, whereby the Curates were exhorted to take care of their Churches, and not to feare the offence of God by not ob≈øeruing the Interdict.

But the Inqui≈øition of Rome the 27. of Iune, prohibited by name this la≈øt Writing, and al≈øo the others not yet imprinted, vnder paine of Excommunication for them that read or kept them: alledging for rea≈øon, that they contained many propo≈øitions, ra≈øh, ≈øcandalous, ≈ølanderous, ≈øeditious, ≈øchi≈ømaticall and hereticall, with this clau≈øe, re≈øpectiue, to make all ambiguous. In the end, they brake off ≈øilence at Rome, whence came out a little Booke of Cardinall Bellarmines again≈øt the Treati≈øes of Ger≈øon, and a little after the Admonition of Cardinall Baronius, full of railing ≈øpeeches and detractions, as al≈øo a Di≈øcour≈øe of Cardinall Colonna, hoping by ≈øuch Writings to moue the fidelitie of all ≈øorts of per≈øons; fora≈ømuch as Card. Colonna
had indeuoured to terrifie the Prelates and other Eccle≈øia≈øtiques placed in the greate≈øt charges by the feare of Cen≈øures, and the priuation of their Dignities and Benefices. Card. Bellarmine aimed to ≈øhake the deuout con≈øciences by exalting the authoritie of the Pope ≈øo far as to make it equall to that of God. And Card. Baronius thought by his reuiling and declaiming to draw to his cau≈øe all learned Per≈øons. They did not beleeue at Rome that any would be found ≈øo bold as to oppo≈øe him≈øelfe to the reputation of the≈øe great Cardinals, con≈øidering their high and eminent qualitie; as al≈øo they hoped to finde that ignorance among the people which they had long laboured to breed and bring in. But at Venice, to the end that no weake con≈øcience might be troubled by the Hyperbolees of Card. Bellarmine, he was ≈øpeedily an≈øwered, to di≈øcouer the truth, and to ≈øhew vnto all what obedience a Chri≈øtian owes to the Soueraigne Bi≈øhop; where al≈øo the publique Rea≈øons were manife≈øted, & the three Ordinances of the Republique maintained, together with their Authority to iudge and puni≈øh Eccle≈øia≈øtiques, which the Pope in his Monitorie had oppugned; with other Writings, intituled, Con≈øiderations and Adui≈øes. And in as
much as it ≈øeemed nece≈ø≈øarie to giue account to all the world, that the commandement made by the Republique for the continuation of Diuine Seruice was iu≈øt and lawfull, they iudged expedient to proue it, by a Treati≈øe of the Interdict: and withall the Senate gaue permi≈ø≈øion to imprint other Bookes in fauour of the publique, prouided that men ≈øhould ob≈øerue herein the Lawes which the State pre≈øcribed, that is, that there ≈øhould be nothing written contrary to faith, good maners, & the Authoritie of Princes. And becau≈øe the Inqui≈øitor was not able to examine all Writings which were pre≈øented to be allowed to the Pre≈ø≈øe, there were deputed fiue Diuines together with the Patriarchall Vicar and the Diuine of the Repub. to take care of tho≈øe matters.

As ≈øoone as the≈øe fore≈øaid Writings appeared in Rome, the Inqui≈øition pre≈øently cen≈øured them, by particular name, becau≈øe (as they ≈øaid) they contained here≈øies, errors and ≈øcandals, with the ordinary clau≈øe, re≈øpectiu√®: and adioyned a Prohibition of all other Writings which ≈øhould be made again≈øt the Interdict, whether in Print or Manu≈øcript, ≈øo as they might not be read or kept without incurring the penalty of Excommunication,
and re≈øeruation of their ab≈øolution. The≈øe prohibitions which might (con≈øidering the terrors of Excommunication) haue repre≈ø≈øed all Writings to be made in fauour of the Republique, did not with≈øtanding produce a contrary effect, fora≈ømuch as many did hence conclude, that rea≈øon could not ≈øtand on their ≈øide, who would not ≈øuffer the Rea≈øons of both parties to be read and publi≈øhed. Others ≈øaid, that the≈øe three Cardinals had di≈øgui≈øed the truth, and would not that it ≈øhould be di≈øcouered. Others thought ≈øtrange that all Writings which might be made were prohibited; as if they pretended to haue the ≈øpirit of prophecie to fore≈øee that men could write nothing good, or el≈øe of authority to extingui≈øh indifferently the good with the euill. There were ≈øome who from this Prohibition collected, that in tho≈øe Writings was nothing worthy of Cen≈øure, ≈øeeing that the Court of Rome had not the boldne≈ø≈øe to note any particular, and by this Aduerbe Re≈øpectiu√®, they had re≈øerued to them≈øelues a ≈øhrowd again≈øt all obiections. Whereupon, ≈øome propo≈øed that for their owne defence again≈øt ≈øuch iniuries, it was meet by publique decree to prohibite all Writings compo≈øed in fauour of the
Pope. But others repre≈øented that this would be to imitate that which they reprehended in another: that the free cour≈øe of the≈øe Writings would be for the aduantage of the Republique, and that hereby men ≈øhould ≈øee that on their part nothing was palliated or di≈øgui≈øed, neither that they di≈øtru≈øted the iudgement of the World vpon that they had done. This opinion preuailed in ≈øuch ≈øort, that not onely the Writings in this Cau≈øe were tolerated, but al≈øo the publique felling of them permitted, and Liberty giuen to bring them into the State.

Touching them that held for the Pope, it is to be noted, that all that time which pa≈ø≈øed from Iuly to that Aprill wherein the Peace was concluded, all ≈øorts of Per≈øons ≈øtriued to be writing to gaine the good grace of his Holine≈ø≈øe. Wherefore there were publi≈øhed many Treati≈øes, as well of Ie≈øuites as of others, partly vnder true names, partly vnder fained; to which Learned meÃÑ made an≈øwers to repell their ≈ølanders, and to confure tho≈øe fal≈øe Doctrines which they attempted to ≈øcatter.

The Doctrine of the Venetian Writers was, in ≈øumme; That God hath e≈øtabli≈øhed two Gouernments in the World, the one Spirituall, and the
other Temporall, each one of them being ≈øupreme and independent vpon the other. The one is the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Mini≈øtery, the other is the Ciuill Gouernment. Of the Spirituall he hath giuen the care vnto the Apo≈øtles, and to their Succe≈ø≈øors; of the Temporall the charge is put in the hands of Princes, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that one may not intermeddle in that which appertaines to the other; that the Pope hath no power to abrogate the Lawes of Princes in Temporall matters, nor to depriue them of their E≈øtates, or free their Subiects from their Allegeance which they owe vnto them; that to depo≈øe Kings from their E≈øtates is a new thing, neuer attempted till within this fiue hundred years, again≈øt the Scriptures, and the examples of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and of his Saints; and that to teach that in ca≈øe of controuer≈øie betweene the Pope and a Prince, it is lawful to pur≈øue him by frauds and open force, or that the Subiects which rebell again≈øt him, doe by that meanes obtaine remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øinnes, is a Doctrine ≈øeditious and ≈øacrilegious; that Eccle≈øia≈øticall men by Diuine Law are not exempted from the Secular Power, neither in their per≈øons nor in their goods; but haue receiued from godly and deuout Princes, ≈øince Con≈øtantine the
Great, vntill Fredericke the ≈øecond, diuers Priuiledges both reall and per≈øonall, greater or le≈ø≈øer according to the exigence of times and places; which hath bin al≈øo practi≈øed in other Realmes and Principalities, being alwayes exempted (as well by Emperours, as other Princes) from the power of inferiour Magi≈øtrates, but not from their owne Soueraigne authority. That the Exemptions granted by Popes vnto the Order of the Clergie haue not beene admitted in ≈øome places, and in others admitted only in part, and that they haue been valide only ≈øo farre as they haue beene receiued; that notwith≈øtanding any Exemption, the Prince hath ≈øtill Power ouer their per≈øons and goods when≈øoeuer nece≈ø≈øity con≈øtraines him to ≈øerue him≈øelfe of them And if at any time they ≈øhould abu≈øe ≈øuch Exemption to the perturbation of the publique tranquillitie, that the Prince is obliged to prouide a remedy. Another point of their Doctrine was, that the Pope ought not to thinke him≈øelfe infallible, vnle≈ø≈øe where God hath promi≈øed him his Diuine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; which ≈øome Moderne Doctors ≈øay to bee onely in nece≈ø≈øary points of Faith, and when hee v≈øes fit meanes to that purpo≈øe, of diuine Inuocation and of Eccle≈øia≈øticall
con≈øultations. But the authority of Binding and Loo≈øing ought to bee vnder≈øtood with this Caution, claue non crrante, ≈øeeing God hath commanded the Pa≈øtor to follow the Merit and Iu≈øtice of the Cau≈øe, and not his owne inclination: that when the Pope vpon any difference with Princes, pa≈ø≈øes on to thunder out his Cen≈øures, it is permitted vnto the Doctors to con≈øider whether he hath proceeded claue errante aut non errante. And the Prince when he is a≈ø≈øured that the Cen≈øures thundred again≈øt him, his E≈øtates and ≈øubiects are inualide, may and ought, for the con≈øeruation of publique peace, hinder the execution thereof, pre≈øeruing his Religion, and the reuerence due to the Church; and that according to the doctrine of S. At the ≈øame time when the An≈øwer of the Senate was ≈øent into France, the Amba≈ø≈øadour of Spaine a≈ø≈øaied to make the Republique yeeld to ≈øome particular, and pre≈øenting him≈øelfe to the Duke, exhorted him to a Compo≈øition: and concluded, that it was nece≈ø≈øary to grant ≈øomething to the King his Ma≈øter, becau≈øe if he might cary a≈ø≈øurance of any ≈øatisfaction vnto the Pope, he would ca≈øt him≈øelfe at his feet, to pray him for an end of the≈øe Differences, which drew with them ≈øo great troubles; That the Pope was not

While≈øt they were con≈øidering this Propo≈øition, being ≈øtill re≈øolued to yeeld nothing preiudiciall to their Liberty, they receiued aduice how the Pope had erected in the beginning of September a new Congregation at Rome, called, The

The ≈øame time Mon≈øieur de Fre≈øne was called by the Senate, with whom they di≈øcour≈øed touching the CoÃÑgregation of War newly erected, and of the Cardinals whereof it con≈øi≈øted, who were ill affected to the Republique and not well to France; wherein the Pope had te≈øtified his ≈ømall re≈øpect of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, not expecting his an≈øwer, which they could not a≈øcribe to any other cau≈øe but the Popes purpo≈øe to pur≈øue the Troubles, who was confident in the declaration of Spaine, not making account of any other, for the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and forces which he expected from thence. And when it ≈øhould plea≈øe him confidently to communicate with them his intentions, they would ≈øend vnto his Maie≈øtie a Per≈øon expre≈øly to treat of particularities. To this the
King an≈øwered, that hee had beene de≈øired by the Nuntio in the name of the Pope, to declare him≈øelfe for his Holine≈ø≈øe; that he would an≈øwer them in like manner as he had an≈øwered the Pope, to wit, that to declare him≈øelfe for either partie wereto foment the Differences, and therefore he would not fauour the purpo≈øes of the one ≈øide or the other, as did the Spaniards for their owne aduantage, but if they ≈øhould di≈øturbe the publique tranquillitie, in that ca≈øe he would doe what be≈øeemed him, and as any one might coniecture: but for the pre≈øent they ought not to pre≈ø≈øe ≈øuch Declarations, but rather ≈øtudie to preuent a rupture for to auoid the incommodities of War, which none can comprehend but they that haue tried them, e≈øpecially con≈øidering the danger of Religion which Warre importeth. Further, they communicated to the Amba≈ø≈øador of England, Re≈øident at Venice, the Preparations which the Pope made at Rome, and told him, that he might now publi≈øh the Declaration of the King his Ma≈øter, and procure the Succours which he promi≈øed; accordingly they gaue order to their Amba≈ø≈øador Iustinian to treat with the King. Moreouer, the Senate determined to ≈øignifie vnto all Princes the Declaration of the King of England. But the King vpon the Repre≈øentation of the Amba≈ø≈øador Iu≈øtinian, an≈øwered, That he called God to witne≈ø≈øe, his re≈øolution to defend the Cau≈øe of the Republique, had no other end but the Seruice of God, and to con≈øerue the Liberty giuen by God to all Princes, and not for any euill will which he carried to the Pope, being not moued by the particular Intere≈øt of the Republique, but only ≈øo farre as he knew they defended a Cau≈øe mo≈øt iu≈øt and acceptable to God: which the more he con≈øidered in his minde, ≈øo much the more was he confirmed in their Protection and Defence, not finding any apparant ≈øhadow of Rea≈øon to relinqui≈øh them: that He had readily taken this re≈øolution, and would
≈øu≈øtaine it con≈øtantly; that He would not doe as the Spaniards, who by a Letter had filled the Popes Spirit with Vanity, to cary Him into a precipice, but that He would execute with courage and ≈øinceritie what He had promi≈øed. For the King of Spaine and the Arch-Duke, he ≈øaid it was to no purpo≈øe to ≈øpeak vnto them, ≈øeeing that the Former had declared him≈øelfe for the Pope, and the Latter depended vpon the former: that for France it was not nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe Spaine being for the Pope, it behoued that King more than others to con≈øider it, and to fore≈øee the enterpri≈øes which might en≈øue again≈øt his Kingdome, ≈øo as formerly he had
experience: that if he beleeued the Defence of the Church to appertaine vnto him, by rea≈øon of his Title of Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian, he might well know that the Church herein was not endangered, but the Cau≈øe in common touched the Libertie of Princes, by whom the Church was to be Protected and Maintained. While≈øt the≈øe things were thus treated with Kings, and by them with the Pope, the great Duke of Tu≈øcany iudged that it would be an action worthy of his great Experience, if he a≈ø≈øayed to fini≈øh that which was ≈øo difficult to two ≈øo great Kings. To
which they alwaies an≈øwered with thankes, and with this conclu≈øion, that he ≈øhould addre≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe rather to the Pope, ≈øince the Republique had ≈øo farre conde≈øcended, that the King of France had thanked them. But the great Duke was not content with this An≈øwer, which gaue no occa≈øion for him to draw the affaire to him≈øelfe; and therefore he complained with great dexteritie, that he had profitably imployed him≈øelfe both with the Pope, and with the Republique, without any corre≈øpondence on their behalfe: on the contrary, that on both ≈øides he had receiued ≈øuch words, which if hee had reported, they had beene ≈øufficient to trouble all the affaire, and to cut off hope of a Conclu≈øion. That his meaning was not to giue coun≈øell vnto the Senate, knowing well their prudence, much le≈ø≈øe to enterpri≈øe to Treat with the preiudice of other greater Princes, but to ioyne with them for the Seruice of God, and of Chri≈øtendome: That he would therefore aduerti≈øe the Republique of all that the Pope had ≈øaid in the la≈øt Audience to his Amba≈ø≈øador, which was, that his Holine≈ø≈øe could not, nor would con≈øent vnto the Conditions propo≈øed by the Amba≈ø≈øador of France; in as much as it ≈øhould be to him a
great preiudice to receiue the Republique to fauour by the hands of any King, being him≈øelfe the Spirituall Head of the Church, to whom it is not ≈øitting to receiue his Subiects at the hand of another: and ≈øo much the more, becau≈øe generally in any difficult betweene the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court and the Secular, the Iudgement thereof pertaineth to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall, as to the more worthy. That the Pope further ≈øaid, that to receiue the Pri≈øoners by the hands of the King, was to goe backward, becau≈øe ≈øome Venetian Prelats which were then at Rome, had a≈ø≈øured him that the Republique would willingly deliuer them to him≈øelfe; That therfore he was re≈øolued not to Su≈øpend the Excommunication before the Pri≈øoners were deliuered, and the Writings reuoked which had beene publi≈øhed in fauour of the Republique: that afterwards hee would be content the Differences remaining might be examined at Rome by a Congregation of Cardinalls, Auditors, and Diuines, whereof a part might be the Confidents of the Republique, vpon Condition notwith≈øtanding that the King of France and the great Duke would pa≈ø≈øe their word, that they would ≈øtand to that which was determined by this Congregation: that although he had
formerly conde≈øcended to an Accord by a reciprocall Su≈øpen≈øion, of his Monitory, and of the Lawes of the Republique, yet he could not execute this Accord, becau≈øe it was not approued by the Cardinalls; That the Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King had ≈øignified vnto him, that the Venetians ought to accept this Condition, but for him≈øelfe, he was not obliged: That if the Venetians had the aid of Heretiques, he would haue on his part more Chri≈øtians than men beleeued. That the great Duke ≈øignified the≈øe particularities to the Republique, to let them ≈øee that there could be no wor≈øe re≈øolution than that which enclined them to Warre again≈øt the Pope, which mu≈øt needs be to their damage; for as much as who≈øoeuer contends in that kinde with him may lo≈øe much, but gaine nothing which it ≈øhall not be meet doubly to re≈øtore. That Warre is profitable to none, e≈øpecially not to them who finde them≈øelues in good e≈øtate, ≈øeeing it produces alterations, and ea≈øily men pa≈ø≈øe therein from better to wor≈øe with little hope of returning. That if the King of France treated in this Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe with great zeale for the good of the Republique, him≈øelfe would not be inferiour to him in a good de≈øire to procure the ≈øame, being their Friend,
an Italian Prince, and a good man: That they ought not to doubt, but if the Warre proceeded, the Pope would be a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Spaniards and others; and therefore to auoid the Troubles of Italy, which might follow, he would per≈øwade the Pope to be contented that all Differences might be referred to the iudgement of the Two Kings, and de≈øired the Republique to doe the ≈øame; yea that he would coun≈øell them to doe this, not expecting the Popes a≈ø≈øent, con≈øidering that ≈øince it was certaine the Pope would not con≈øent to this motion, becau≈øe it was to ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to the iudgement of another, the Republique hereby might gaine ≈øome aduantage by putting the Pope in diffidence with the≈øe Kings, and by taking away the courage of the Spaniards for his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. And although the Pope ≈øhould con≈øent, yet the Republique might be a≈ø≈øured, that the Kings in the deci≈øion would haue re≈øpect to their owne Intere≈øts, which were the ≈øame with tho≈øe of the Republique. That of this Propo≈øition were not admitted, then be had another peraduenture ≈øome what more difficult, but which would certainly better ≈øucceed, if they would make ≈øome ≈ømall Expences; which it behoued them not to reiect, for as much
as a ≈øea≈øonable Expence is ordinarily very effectuall. That hee knew well what hee ≈øaid, hauing a great Friend in Court, the Lord Iohn Bapti≈øt Borghe≈øe, the Popes Brother; that if they would giue way, with a little ≈øiluer hee would a≈ø≈øuredly bring the Controuer≈øie to a good agreement. To the≈øe Propo≈øuious the Senate an≈øwered, after they had thanked the great Duke for the communication of all that which he knew from Rome, as al≈øo for his good Offices, Coun≈øels and Di≈øcour≈øes; that the inclinatioÃÑ of the Republique to Peace was knowne to all the World, in which they purpo≈øed ≈øtill to continue, prouided that they were not con≈øtrained to doe otherwi≈øe: al≈øo they had giuen hereof good Te≈øtimony, ≈øeeing that not hauing no regard to Offences receiued, & to the iu≈øtice of their Cau≈øe, which required that Iniuries ≈øhould be thorowly repaied, before they gaue care to any Conditions of Peace; they had notwith≈øtanding not only kept open the way vnto The Treaty, and harkned to the Propo≈øitions which had beene made, but had further yeelded ≈øo far as they were able at the in≈øtance of the Two Kings. And although they had done ≈øo much, and that the King of France was not
onely fully ≈øatisfied touching their actions, but had al≈øo ≈øent expre≈øly to thanke them, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe they could not yet ≈øee any effect of the Treaty of that King with the Pope; and therefore the Republique was obliged to ≈øtand to that which they had treated with the King, and expected what his Maie≈øtie would doe in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, iudging it not fit to interrupt the treaty which hee had enterpri≈øed: but in the meane while, that they would ≈øay confidently, there were many and vnauoidable difficulties in tho≈øe things which the Pope had ≈øignified vnto him by his Amba≈ø≈øador. For touching the point of the Pri≈øoners, hauing giuen them vnto the King, they had no more to doe in them, nor was it in them now to take any other re≈øolution. And for that which concerned the Writings, tho≈øe of Rome being fir≈øt publi≈øhed, and full of iniuries, reuilings and calumnies, whereunto they were of nece≈ø≈øity to make an≈øwer with mode≈øtie, it was not meet to vrge them, if they did not fir≈øt of all, or at lea≈øt at the ≈øame time, vrge again≈øt tho≈øe of Rome. For the Congregation to which the Pope would remit the affaire, it was not needfull to ≈øay much, the Republique being not accu≈øtomed to refer vnto the
deci≈øion of another, ≈øuch things as coucerne their Gouernment. And for the other Propo≈øitions of his Highne≈ø≈øe, ≈øince that the Popes fa≈øhion of proceeding gaue iu≈øt ≈øu≈øpition that he was not di≈øpo≈øed vnto Peace, they could not examine them, vnle≈ø≈øe they had greater certaintie of his intentions: and ≈øeeing all former Treaties had produced no good effect, by rea≈øon of the Popes incon≈øtancie well knowne to his Highne≈ø≈øe, the Republique ≈øaw clearely it was to no purpo≈øe to harken to any further propo≈øitions, or to oblige them≈øelues by their word in any points without a reciprocall a≈ø≈øurance on his behalfe. But when (after the remouing of the Cen≈øures) they ≈øhould ≈øee any appearance of an amicable temperameÃÑt, which might efface the iu≈øt apprehen≈øions which they had of his ordinarie incon≈øtancie, they would con≈øider thereof adui≈øedly, and end all with re≈øolution; that which could not be done ≈øo long as matters were handled by di≈øcour≈øe. To this an≈øwer made by the Re≈øident in the name of the Senate, the great Duke replied, that the Pope was not ill affected, although haply ≈øome accidents had troubled him, which he could affirme out of his certaine knowledge: and that although he
≈øeemed to be altered, yet when his Amba≈ø≈øador did repre≈øent vnto him the things afore≈øaid, he confirmed them; and he adioyned, that he had cau≈øed many Propo≈øitions to be made to the Republique, and yet could not preuaile to know their intentions: That it was meet to vnder≈øtand the one the other; That treaties prepare the way to conclu≈øions, and that if they ≈øhould tru≈øt him with any thing he would make v≈øe thereof to the aduantage of the Republique, his purpo≈øe being not to di≈øcouer all at once vnto the Pope which he had to tell him, but to re≈øerue a part to ≈øerue him≈øelfe thereof as occa≈øion required, not meaning to doe as others, who had not drawne from the Pope any re≈øolution, although they had propo≈øed many things to his aduantage.

The interpo≈øing of ≈øo many Princes for the according of the≈øe Differences, moued al≈øo the Emperour to haue his part therein: and to this effect, he ≈øent in the beginning of October his Vice-Chancelor named Coraducci, to the Amba≈ø≈øador of the Repub. Soranzo, Re≈øident with him, for to tell him, that his Maie≈øtie vnder≈øtanding that the Differences betweene the Pope and the Republique were ≈øo far pa≈ø≈øed, that the agreement
thereof was very difficult, e≈øpecially ≈øince the King of France ≈øeemed ready to for≈øake the Treaty, Him≈øelfe was once purpo≈øed for the good of Chri≈øtendome (which he pa≈ø≈øionately de≈øired,) to employ him≈øelfe for the ≈øetling of a Peace betweene the two parties, if he had thought that his trauell herein would be accepted, and that he might performe it with honour: but ≈øince both of them were ≈øo re≈øolute not to yeeld any thing the one to the other, he could not hazard therein his dignity and reputation. Soranzo an≈øwered, after he had thanked his Maie≈øtie; that the Republique was ready to doe all they could po≈ø≈øibly to preuent the trouble of the publique Tranquillitie, ≈øauing euer their Liberty, their Dignity, and the Intere≈øts of their E≈øtate: but that the Pope would needs carry all, and pretended that all ought to yeeld vnto his Will without any demurre or conte≈øtation. The Vice-Chancellor, after ≈øome Di≈øcour≈øes vpon the Points, replied, that the Emperour would not demand any thing of the Republique which might be again≈øt their Honour, and that he would ≈øend the Marqui≈øe of Ca≈øtillon with good in≈øtructions. After this the Nuntio of the Pope and the Amba≈ø≈øador of Spaine did
all they could to cau≈øe the Emp. to decalre him≈øelfe for the Pope; to whom the Emperor freely an≈øwered, That He thought not fit to declare him≈øelfe for either part, or to make ≈øuch offers as ≈øome had made by Letters and other ≈øuch Apparences, this tending to countenance and incourage very exorbitant Preten≈øions; That He wi≈øhed Peace might be e≈øtabli≈øhed in any ca≈øe, and being re≈øolued to bend him≈øelfe this way, he would not do a thing whereby Peace might be hindered. And in priuate, he gaue the Amba≈øs. of Spaine to vnder≈øtand, that for the publique quiet of Chri≈øtendome, the King his Ma≈øter ought to mortifie in ≈øome ≈øort the Pope, to the end that being reduced to Rea≈øon, hee might more ea≈øily admit the Peace. The≈øe things when the Amba≈ø≈øador Soranzo had writ to Venice, he had charge to thanke the Emp. and to certifie him of their inclination to Peace, and further to tell Him, that the Senate would e≈øteeme it a great Honour, if his Maie≈øtie would be plea≈øed to induce the Pope to content him≈øelfe with tho≈øe offers which they had made by the means and in con≈øideration of the King of France.

div.head: FIFTH BOOKE.
div.p:
THE time was thus ≈øpent in Treaties, vntill the end of October, when the Pope began to take into his con≈øideration, that ≈øo long as this ≈øeparation of the Republique from his obedience continued, his reputation would be more and more endamaged: becau≈øe the Bookes written in their Defence had opened the eyes of many, and the Liberty of Speech had made knowne the great Defects of the Court of Rome, which formerly many men did not ≈øo well con≈øider. Moreouer, hee ob≈øerued by Treating with the Spaniards vpon the particularities of the ≈øuccours which they had promi≈øed, that the Effects were not an≈øwerable to their Words, ≈øince they propo≈øed hard Conditions; and further gaue him to vnder≈øtand, that it did not agree with the Piety of the Catholique King to be the cau≈øe of a Warre in Italy: wherefore that he was not di≈øpo≈øed to ≈øuccour him but in ca≈øe that hee ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øaulted. For the≈øe cau≈øes, the Pope
re≈øoluing in him≈øelfe to ≈øee an end of this Affaire hee called Alincourt the Amba≈ø≈ø. of France, to whom hee made a long Di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øhewing that he acknowledged all the≈øe Di≈øorders; and repeating the Damages and Preiudices which he ≈øuffered, with the Dangers to which he was expo≈øed, he te≈øtified his great de≈øire of an Agreement in any ≈øort, a≈ø≈øuring him to this effect of his good intention. And fora≈ømuch as it was not honourable for him to begin the motion, he promi≈øed to be ready to accept any rea≈øonable Propo≈øition. He proceeded al≈øo to touch ≈øome Particulars, but ≈øo as he ≈øeemed not willing to propound them.

Alincourt hauing communicated the≈øe things to the French Cardinals, they adui≈øed to propo≈øe vnto the Republique by Fre≈øne a motion with the≈øe Conditions; That the Pope ≈øhould take away the Cen≈øures, after he had beene praied in the name of the King and the Repub. and that fir≈øt of all the Interdict ≈øhould be ob≈øerued for the ≈øpace of 4. or 5. daies; That the Pri≈øoners ≈øhould be rendred to the Pope by way of Gratification to the King; That the Letters of the D. ≈øhould be reuoked; That the Writings publi≈øhed in fauour of the Repub. ≈øhould be ≈øuppre≈øted;
That the Religious gone out of the State onely by rea≈øon of the Interdict, ≈øhould be ree≈øtabli≈øhed; That they ≈øhould ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador to thanke the Pope for opening the way vnto a friendly Treaty, That they ≈øhould ≈øpeake no more of reuoking or ≈øu≈øpending the Lawes, but onely of taking away the Cen≈øures; and for the difficulties remaining betweene the Pope and the Republique, they ≈øhould Treat as one Prince with another; That a certaine day might bee prefixed, to the end that at the ≈øame time the Republique and the Pope might doe what was agreed vpon, that neither the one nor the other might be ≈øaid to haue begun fir≈øt. Fre≈øne made accordingly the≈øe Propo≈øitions, hauing fir≈øt confe≈ø≈øed, that the Republique was not in any nece≈ø≈øitie to admit the Accord for feare of being forced, becau≈øe hee knew very well both the Power of the Republique, and the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance which they ≈øhould haue: But fora≈ømuch as ≈øome of their A≈ø≈øi≈øtants were ≈øuch as did not acknowledge the Church of Rome, the Senate in their wi≈ødome would thinke meet not to make v≈øe of them, how≈øoeuer they readily offered them≈øelues. The Senate, when they had maturely con≈øidered all things, an≈øwered, that they were
contented the Pope might be praied by the Amba≈ø≈øador of the King in the name of the Republique to take away the Cen≈øures; That the Pri≈øoners ≈øhould be giuen vnto the King, without preiudice of the Rea≈øons of the Republique; That for the Prote≈øtation made by the Duke again≈øt the Monitorie of the Pope, it ≈øhould not faile to be retracted when the Cen≈øures were taken away. And for the other Writings the Republique would doe with them as the Pope with tho≈øe which had beene made in Fauour of him: That to ob≈øerue the Interdict for one onely houre (not to ≈øpeake of daies) was to confe≈ø≈øe that it was valide: which being vntrue, they could not doe it without offending God, and condemning the Actions of the Republique, which were but iu≈øt and lawfull. For the Religious, that this was no point of the Treaty, but onely with his Holine≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe: That the Cen≈øures being once remoued, they would ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador to re≈øide in Rome according to the Cu≈øtome. But all this vpon condition that the Mini≈øters of the King would openly let them vnder≈øtand that they had a≈ø≈øurance from the Pope; becau≈øe otherwi≈øe they did not meane to conde≈øcend to
any thing, vnle≈ø≈øe they were a≈ø≈øured that the Pope would accept the Condition. To this Fre≈øne replied, that he had not propo≈øed the≈øe things if the Pope had not fir≈øt giuen his word; but he hath giuen it, ≈øaid he, and repeated foure times, he hath giuen it: and adioyned, that although it was true, that Popes ≈øometime giue them≈øelues a Licen≈øe to retract their words, yet he beleeued that this Man would con≈øtantly keepe his, hauing giuen it. Wherefore he ≈øaid, that he accepted the Conditions, and took their word, to pray the Pope in the Name of the King and of the Republique, to take away his Cen≈øures. And in like manner, that they would ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador, who, according as the Pope had promi≈øed to Alincourt, ≈øhould be receiued with accu≈øtomed Honour. Adding, that hee would receiue the Pri≈øoners in the Name of the King, by way of meere Gratification, and without preiudice of the Rea≈øons of the Republique; that the Pope indeed would not make hereof any Declaration, but that ≈øhould re≈øt vpon the King, and the Popes Declaration in this ca≈øe was not needfull to the Republique, in as much as they Treated not with the Pope, but with the King. Concerning the Religious, he ≈øaid: I ≈øhall
be for them indeed a cold Aduocate, becau≈øe they cannot deny but they haue committed a great error in di≈øobeying their Prince contrary to the Commandement of God, and ≈øeeing it behoueth them e≈øpecially to Preach Obedience ≈øo ≈øtraitly enioyned by God. Be≈øides that hauing abandoned their Country, wherin they were wel treated and entertained, their ingratitude herein is ≈øo intollerable, that if it belonged to me, I ≈øhould cau≈øe them to be decimated for example vnto others. He added, That the facility of the Republique was very great, in that they con≈øented that their Amba≈ø≈øador might Treat of their Matter with his Holine≈ø≈øe. And concluded his Di≈øcour≈øe, by giuing thankes in the Name of his King, for that which they had done to gratifie him, a≈ø≈øuring them that he would acknowledge their good di≈øpo≈øition to publique. Tranquillitie, hauing in truth done as much as was conuenient.

While≈øt the≈øe things were thus treated, the King of France receiued aduice of the Popes incon≈øtancy, & of the great Dukes practi≈øes to interpo≈øe him≈øelfe in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, to whom the Pope gaue care: whereupon he was di≈øplea≈øed both with the great Duke for medling in his Negotiation,
and al≈øo with the Pope, commanding his Amba≈ø≈øador to make complaint vnto him, and to ≈øhew him that he had but little confidence in his Holine≈ø≈øe. And the King made the ≈øame complaint vnto Cardinall Barberino, the Popes Nuntio, Re≈øident with him; and by Fre≈øne he told them at Venice, That he thanked the Senate for that they had pa≈ø≈øed their word not to conclude the Affaire by the Mediation of any other but of him, although the Popes incon≈øtancie con≈øtrained him to permit, that his Serenitie might endeuour to doe by other meanes what he could. But when Alincourt had ≈øignified vnto the Pope the commandement of the King, which was, that his Maie≈øtie had charged him not to meddle further in the Affaire of Venice, ≈øeeing his Holine≈ø≈øe imagined he could better accommodate the Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe by the Mediation of others: the Pope who was already aduerti≈øed by Letters from Cardinall Barberino, and prepared for his an≈øwer, excu≈øed him≈øelfe, that he could not hinder the zeale which ≈øome Others might haue to determine this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and much le≈ø≈øe v≈øe inciuility by refu≈øing their offers: but that notwith≈øtanding he had alwaies great confidence in his Maie≈øtie, and his De≈øigne was
that all might be done by his hand: and he affirmed with many oathes often repeated, that his intention was very good, and that he wi≈øhed the Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe might be ended that very houre, if it were po≈ø≈øible, and that not any other be≈øides the King might haue part therein. And to ≈øhew by effects the truth of that which he ≈øaid, he adioyned, that he would be content with the Conditions propo≈øed by his Maie≈øtie, and would firmely hold the word which he had giuen, to erect a Congregation of Six Cardinals, and ≈øo many Auditors, among whom he would put the Cardinals Delfin, Mantica, and Seraphin, and for Auditors, Cuccina, and Marquemont. Alincourt here much maruailing, replied, That no ≈øuch thing had beene formerly ≈øpoken off: But the Pope affirming the contrary, the Amba≈ø≈øador mode≈øtly ≈øaid, That he had not ≈øo vnder≈øtood it; and that it was certaine, the Republique was re≈øolued not to referre them≈øelues to any Congregation After many Replies on either Part, the Pope was content to giue his word, that no more ≈øhould be ≈øpoken of a Congregation; and then he di≈øcour≈øed on the other Conditions, hauing fir≈øt prayed Alincourt, for the loue of God to keepe all ≈øecret, for as much as the Spaniards ob≈øerued all
that was treated, to di≈øturbe it. He promi≈øed to take away the Cen≈øures, prouided that in exchange the Republique ≈øhould giue a≈ø≈øurance to execute the≈øe Conditions; That the Pri≈øoners ≈øhould be con≈øigned into the hands of a Prelate, whom he ≈øhould name; That an Amba≈ø≈øadour ≈øhould come to demand that the Cen≈øures might be remoued, who ≈øhould pre≈øent him≈øelfe with Alincourt, with promi≈øe that he ≈øhould be well treated and receiued; That on the day appointed they ≈øhould reuoke the Prote≈øtation, with all that thereupon had followed; That the Religious ≈øhould be recalled; and that he might haue a≈ø≈øurance of the King, that while≈øt the Amba≈ø≈øador ≈øhould Treat with him, the Lawes ≈øhould not be executed: Adding, that what≈øoeuer he did herein, was for no other Rea≈øon, but for the Dignity of the See Apo≈øtolique, & for his charge. And here he inlarged him≈øelfe with vehement words and ge≈øtures to per≈øwade the≈øe Propo≈øitions, adioyning notwith≈øtanding, that he was not certain whether He could in Con≈øi≈øtory draw all the Cardinals to his opinion. Alincourt replied, that for the Amba≈ø≈øador to be ≈øent, no ≈øuch Condition had beene propo≈øed. The Pope ≈øaid, that otherwi≈øe he could doe nothing, this tending to
con≈øerue his reputation, and to ≈øhew the validitie of the Excommunication. Alincourt made an≈øwer, that rea≈øon concluded the contrary, in as much as the receiuing of an Amba≈ø≈øador with Honour and v≈øual complements, rather implied the inualidity of the Excommunication. But for all that he could ≈øay as well vpon this point as others, he could nothing preuaile; for the Pope concluded, that thus he ≈øhould write to Fre≈øne, and no otherwi≈øe. Who reporting the≈øe words vnto the Senate, added, That in this point hee would not per≈øwade them to one thing or to other, but only demanded that he might haue their an≈øwer.

The Duke immediatly with vehemency complained, that in ≈øtead of approaching to an end by the≈øe Treaties, things were further off, the Differences being imbittered by this alteration of minds: ≈øince that the Pope being not willing to hold his word, which he had giuen, this was openly to declare that he would either do thus, or carry all; That it was little for the credit of ≈øo great a King, to intermeddle in this Affaire, ≈øince the word once giuen him was reuoked: Wherefore that it was not meet to labour any more, for it was nothing but vainly to ≈øpend
time, ≈øeeing that to yeeld that which the Pope Propo≈øed, was indeed to yeeld all the Cau≈øe, which if they had beene willing to doe, they could haue done it without any mediation of any Per≈øon.
