Wherefore that it was not meet to breake all at once, on the ≈øudden, but to gaine time to make preparations, and to receiue Succours; and he beleeued that the Succours were ready for defence of the Republique, and therefore it was nece≈ø≈øary that they ≈øhould declare what aids in particular they de≈øired in this occa≈øion. That certainly the Republique
could doe no le≈ø≈øe than ≈øu≈øtaine their Dignitie by force, ≈øeeing that hauing ≈øhewed them≈øelues ≈øen≈øible of the iniuries receiued from the Pope, and hauing notwith≈øtanding conde≈øcended in Fauour of the Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, ≈øo far as they might; if at the pre≈øent they ≈øhould yeeld any further, it would appeare that they had been con≈øtant and made great ≈øhewes, ≈øo long as men treated by words, but that after the noi≈øe of the Spani≈øh Armies they had ba≈øely relented. And as the K. his Ma≈øter was obliged, becau≈øe they had done ≈øo much in his con≈øideration, ≈øo ≈øhould he be free, if they ≈øhould doe for others what they would not for him. And to the end that the Senate might not re≈øt doubtfull any longer what was the finall will of the Pope, Fre≈øne ≈øaid hee would clearely reueale it vnto them, and this it was; That his Holine≈ø≈øe would haue the Kings word, that the Lawes ≈øhould not be executed by the Republique, and that not by way of Ceremony, but becau≈øe his reall intention was that it ≈øhould be indeed performed, vntill they might further Treat thereof, de≈øiring to ha≈øten the Treaty vnto a Conclu≈øion, that it be not put off ad Kalendas Graecas; That he would examine the Lawes deliberately, with re≈øolution to haue
them abrogated if they were found vniu≈øt, but if he found them good and conuenient, he would enioyne the Eccle≈øia≈øtiques by a Bull to ob≈øerue them, as made by the See Apo≈øtolique, and not as Lawes of the Republique, who could not e≈øtabli≈øh them: Further, that his Holine≈ø≈øe was firme and con≈øtant to haue a re≈øtitution of all the Religious, and ≈øpecially of the Ie≈øuites. Hee ≈øaid moreouer, that they needed not to de≈øpaire of an Agreement, if the Treaty were pur≈øued (as it had beene begunne) by the King his Ma≈øter, who≈øe Propo≈øitions were as different from tho≈øe of the Spaniards, as are tho≈øe of a Friend and of an Enemie, in as much as the Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King did not enter into this Affaire as obliged vnto the Pope: That notwith≈øtanding it was nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øurcea≈øe the Treaty for a while, ≈øeeing it could not be continued, but with di≈øaduantage, the Armies being leuied, and any ≈øhew of feare would puffe vp the Spaniards with pride. But if by their refu≈øall they did occa≈øion Don Francis de Ca≈øtro to retire, the King might then after continue the Treatie, wherein he would imploy him≈øelfe with affection. And if they imagined the Pope might be wonne by faire meanes, hee iudged fit that they ≈øhould ≈øignifie all vnto the
King by ≈øome expre≈ø≈øe and capable Per≈øon. The Senate an≈øwered (thanking the King for his good will, and for this Declaration,) that they had not failed to put all in order both in the Territory of Vicenza, and in all their State: And that the Count de Fuentes, or who≈øoeuer ≈øhould attempt any ≈øuch enterpri≈øe, ≈øhould finde ≈øtrong and able re≈øi≈øtance; That now nothing remained but that it would plea≈øe the King to let them ≈øee what the Republique might promi≈øe them≈øelues from his Maie≈øtie, in ca≈øe that nece≈ø≈øitie ≈øhould force them to breake the Treaty, being ≈øtill mo≈øt re≈øolute to maintaine their Libertie and Dignity giuen by God, vntill the la≈øt breath without the lea≈øt relenting; which they de≈øired to know more particularly, con≈øidering that the Proui≈øions made, and ≈øtill increa≈øed by the Spaniards, required ≈øome a≈ø≈øurance; that the Republique would powerfully a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Gri≈øons, and immediately execute what they promi≈øed, ≈øo ≈øoone as they were ≈øecured of Succour for their owne indemnity, which they mu≈øt be ≈øpeedily, de≈øiring to haue that Succour ≈øpecified, that they might Treat thereof with his Maie≈øtie, which they would doe by meanes of their Amba≈ø≈øador Priuli, and if it were needfull they would ≈øend
an Extraordinary: That touching the Treaties of Don Francis de Ca≈øtro, they had communicated all that was done to Fre≈øne him≈øelfe, who confe≈ø≈øed it nece≈ø≈øary that they mu≈øt giue him an an≈øwer, which he demanded continually with great in≈øtance. And it was very true that Don Francis often pre≈øented him≈øelfe, vrging to haue ≈øome an≈øwer to his Propo≈øition.

For, the Holidaies were no ≈øooner pa≈øt, but hee appeared in the Senate, ≈øaying, That his thoughts were ≈øtill bent on the Agreement, and that he had ≈øpent already 53. dayes ≈øince his Arriuall, during which he might ≈øay he had done nothing, although he demanded but a very ≈ømall thing, to wit, a Su≈øpen≈øion for ≈øome time, with which he was a≈ø≈øured the Pope would be contented; That if he would not, the Catholique King would cea≈øe to fauour him, who wi≈øhed indeed the contentment of the Republique, but yet after that of the Pope; for who≈øe ≈øatisfaction, when the Repub. ≈øhould haue done ≈øomewhat in gratification of his King, he would ca≈øt him≈øelfe at the Popes feet, and would not ri≈øe till he had obtained of his Holine≈ø≈øe ≈øome Honourable ≈øatisfaction for the Repub. from whom that did not ≈øuffice which had beene yeelded in
Fauour of the King of France, ≈øince it ≈øtood not with the Dignity of the Catholique King to ≈øpeak vpon others trauailes, and of things already reiected by the Pope. That he was not vnwilling therefore to ioyne with the French Amba≈ø≈øador, for as much as his King refu≈øed not CoÃÑpanions in this good work, but he de≈øired to know what kinde of Vnion he might haue with the French: that he expected an≈øwers more cleare and ample than had beene giuen him. That de≈øiring a good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in this Affaire, he had waited, & would yet wait with patience, but he looked for ≈øome Declaration of what might be done by vniting him≈øelfe with the French: And that he would yet againe ≈øollicite Fre≈øne, to ≈øee whether yet he had a purpo≈øe to demand of the Senate, that they might pa≈ø≈øe their word that the Lawes ≈øhould not be executed, while≈øt the Accord was Treating. And if this Propo≈øition were not admitted, that he would re≈øolue to take his la≈øt farewell of his Commi≈ø≈øion, being already vexed and tired with ≈øo tedious delayes, by which he had acquired little Honour. There was not any weeke wherein Don Francis did not once at lea≈øt, but v≈øually oftner, ≈øhew him≈øelfe in Senate, with the ≈øame Propo≈øition, notwith≈øtanding that he had
alwaies the ≈øame An≈øwer; becau≈øe he had continuall CoÃÑmandements from Spaine, rather to pre≈ø≈øe with importunity the≈øe things, than to relent a whit. As al≈øo they charged the Count de Fuentes to Arme, but with command not to moue farther wth out new Order, altho he were prouoked by the Gri≈øons, or by Others. And becau≈øe Don Francis offering to vnite him≈øelfe with the French, found not in them ≈øuch corre≈øpondence as he expected, he could not containe him≈øelfe (about the end of Ianuary) from complaining of the ≈ømall re≈øpect which he had receiued from them; ≈øaying, That a≈ø≈øuredly the Pope would remoue the Cen≈øures, prouided that he might haue a≈ø≈øurance that the Lawes ≈øhould not be executed; That they might and ought to beleeue him herein, as hauing neuer varied in his Treaties. That the Affaire was in great di≈øorder, becau≈øe it had not beene ≈øincerely treated by the Mediators, who how≈øoeuer they pretended a de≈øire of Peace, yet peraduenture aimed at other ends; which could not be truly affirmed of his King, who had as great intere≈øt in the Repo≈øe of Italy, as the Repub. That hauing ≈øo frequently propo≈øed the≈øe things to the Senate, it ≈øeemed to him high time for them to returne him an an≈øwer.

div.head: SIXTH BOOKE.
div.p:
DVring the≈øe Treaties at Venice, in France, the Amba≈ø≈øador Priuli propo≈øed vnto the King that which the Senate had giuen him in charge, that it would plea≈øe his Maie≈øtie to declare him. him≈øelfe. He an≈øwered, that it was yet not conuenient to doe it, to the end that neither partie ≈øhould per≈øeuere in their ≈øtiffene≈ø≈øe: That he had receiued Letters from all the Princes of Italie and other Grandies, who praied him to endeuour a conclu≈øion of the≈øe Debates: propo≈øing vnto him, that as the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe herein could not but aduance his Glory, ≈øo to retire him≈øelfe ≈øhould be to draw vpon him the fault of all ≈øini≈øter effects which might follow. Therefore, that he had di≈øpatched a commandement to the Cardinall de Ioyeu≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe into Italy, and effectually to interpo≈øe in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. To which the Amba≈ø≈øador replied, hauing commended the good will of the King to Peace, that there appeared little corre≈øpondence in the Pope, who
prided him≈øelfe in the promi≈øes of the Spaniards: That he doubted not but They being for the Pope, his Maie≈øtie would ≈øtand for the Repub. Fre≈øne hauing giuen his word in his Name to that effect, e≈øpecially ≈øince the Republique at the in≈øtance of his Maie≈øtie were di≈øpo≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Gri≈øons. Here the King ≈øaid, that in a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Gri≈øons the Repub. ≈øhould doe them≈øelues a good ≈øeruice, both to con≈øerue the amitie of that Nation, & to keep the pa≈ø≈øage open: That Fre≈øne had no commi≈ø≈øion from him to come to particulars: That he knew no what he had ≈øaid or promi≈øed, but He vnder≈øtood him≈øelfe not to be obliged: And further he ≈øaw clearely, that to declare him≈øelfe were nothing el≈øe but to loo≈øe his Authority with the Pope, but of that he would make an≈øwer more particularly by Villeroy. Who after told him from the King, that his Maie≈øtie hauing a good hope of the Agreement, le≈øt hee ≈øhould interrupt or trouble the Treaty (≈øo long as any point thereof was a foot) he would not declare him≈øelfe: That for this rea≈øon he had writ to the Card. de Ioyeu≈øe that he ≈øhould ≈øpeedily goe to Venice, and from thence to Rome; in the meane while he would write to his Amba≈ø≈øador that he ≈øhould proceed
with efficacie: And conformably to this he had giuen order to Fre≈øne to tell the Venetians: That the King had certaine aduice, that on the Popes part there was not any difficultie touching the promi≈øes, and that with the≈øe conditions mentioned, all Controuer≈øies might be accommodated, to wit, That the Pri≈øoners ≈øhould be deliuered into the hands of an Eccle≈øia≈øticall Commi≈ø≈øarie: That an Amba≈ø≈ø. ≈øhould be ≈øent towards the Pope, who being come to a place appointed, the Pope would take away the Cen≈øures, as al≈øo the ≈øame day at Venice they ≈øhould take away the Prote≈øtation; and this being done, the Amba≈ø≈øador ≈øhould continue his iourney, and be receiued at Rome according to the ordinary cu≈øtome, being not with≈øtanding accompanied to the fir≈øt Audience by Alincourt. And becau≈øe the Pope wi≈øhed the Kings word that the Republique ≈øhould not v≈øe their Lawes, the King was ready and de≈øired to giue it, ≈øo that the Republique by ≈øome ≈øigne would giue con≈øent, to a≈ø≈øure him that his word ≈øhould be executed: That for the Ie≈øuites he beleeued the thing to be without difficultie, how≈øoeuer the King ≈øpeaking with the Amba≈ø≈øador Priuli had found therein great re≈øi≈øtance, and a ≈øtronger re≈øolution
then his Maie≈øtie expected, ≈øo far that Priuli ≈øaid, that ≈øometimes the Republique had had all the Princes of Europe banded again≈øt them, yet had not de≈øpaired nor had beene willing therefore to do them≈øelues any preiudice: That neuerthele≈ø≈øe he hoped not to finde ≈øo great re≈øi≈øtance from his Serenitie, but that in gratification of his Maie≈øtie they would con≈øent to the≈øe two Points. The Duke, con≈øidering the preiudices which would come of the≈øe two things, immediately an≈øwered, That this were to make the world beleeue that the Republique had committed ≈øome fault; That it was a means to make them of Rome in≈øolent, and giue them occa≈øion to conceiue Preten≈øions aboue all Princes, if they ≈øhould thus carry the matter again≈øt the Republique. That the Pri≈øoners had beene giuen to the King, and to him it appertained to doe with them as he plea≈øed: But the Republique could doe nothing more, and would neuer con≈øent to ≈øend an Amba≈ø≈øador, before the Pope, by reuoking the Cen≈øures, had ≈øatisfied for the iniuries. That the offences receiued from the Ie≈øuites were too exce≈ø≈øiue, and of too great importance, hauing in≈øtigated the Pope, and defamed the Republique throughout all Chri≈øtian
States: That it was not meet to ree≈øtabli≈øh their Enemies after the example of others, and if others had ≈øometime done it, they had beene gouerned therein by their Intere≈øts, different froÃÑ tho≈øe of the Repub. That euery one knowes what is fit for his owne particular, and what is done in one E≈øtate is not therefore meet to be executed in all. For the Cardinall de Ioyeu≈øe if he came he ≈øhould be very welcome and honourably entertained, but they much more de≈øired that hee ≈øhould turne him≈øelfe towards Rome, where his employment was much more nece≈ø≈øarie to reduce the Pope to point of rea≈øon: becau≈øe the Republique hauing yeelded all that they could, there was no more to be done, but at Rome, where the remainder ought to bee Treated.

By all the≈øe Treaties it appeared that the Pope was little inclined to any Concord, vnle≈ø≈øe it might be with his great aduantage, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the Spaniards to continue their warlike proui≈øions. But aboue all he gaue a manife≈øt ≈øigne of a minde vtterly auer≈øe from Peace, when he declared the day of Ianuary in full Con≈øi≈øtorie, that he would haue Warre with the Republique of Venice; That to this effect he had
from the King of Spaine 26000. foot, and 4000. hor≈øe, and named the Cardinall Borghe≈øe his Nephew to be his Legate with 1000. Crownes a Moneth for proui≈øion. This declaration of the Pope ioyned to the preparations of the Spaniards, were little plea≈øing to the Princes of Italy, and particularly to the Duke of Sauoy, the great Duke of Tu≈øcany, and to the Duke of Mantua; who con≈øidered very prudently, how much it imported, that the Spaniards had ≈øo great forces in Italy, and that the Pope had ca≈øt him≈øelfe intirely into their hands. The Duke of Sauoy ob≈øerued it ≈øo much more iealou≈øly, becau≈øe he had beene iutreated by the Count Fuentes to fill vp his companies of hor≈øe, to receiue within his Countrey ≈øome of his Troupes, and to put in his hands the Fortre≈ø≈øe of Carbonara, to hinder the Huguenots of France to pa≈ø≈øe vnto the ≈øuccour of the Venetians: giuing his word that ≈øo ≈øoone as the Republique of Venice ≈øhould be vanqui≈øhed (which hee ≈øaid would be within three Moneths,) hee would withdraw his ≈øouldiers and leaue the Countrey free; wherewith the Duke was much grieued, and complained thereof in Spaine. And the Duke of Mantua being required to lodge the Neapolitans within Montferrat,
excu≈øed him≈øelfe not only vnto the Count but al≈øo to the King: who ≈øent order to Milan that the Duke ≈øhould not be pre≈ø≈øed. But to diuert the cour≈øe of the≈øe di≈øorders, the Duke of Sauoy Treated with the Pope by the Count de Ver√ºa his Amba≈ø≈øador, that he would ioyne him≈øelfe with the great Duke of Tu≈øcany, and that they would put together good forces to ≈øuccour him: and on the other ≈øide, the ≈øame Duke ≈øignified to the Senate of Venice the offers which he had made vnto the Pope, prote≈øting that he made them not to offend the Republique, or to ≈øtrengthen the Pope further for the Warre, but to the end that the Pope ≈øhould not wholly ca≈øt him≈øelfe into the hands of Spaniards.

But the Pope did not take in good part this Amba≈ø≈øage of the Count de Ver√ºa: on the contrary, he maruailed that his Ma≈øter did not ioy ne his intention with the Spaniards. Wherefore he began to ≈øu≈øpect his iourney to Venice, and wi≈øhed him to con≈øider that for the ob≈øtinacie (≈øo he ≈øpake) of the Venetians nothing could be done, and therefore exhorted him not to hazard ≈øo his reputation.

In Spaine the Duke of Lerma complained to the Amba≈ø≈øador of England of the Demon≈øtrations
of a≈ø≈øi≈øtance which his King had made in fauour of the Republique, ≈øaying, that they had not ≈øhewed them≈øelues ≈øo re≈øolute again≈øt the Pope, if they had not been encouraged by his King; becau≈øe from France they could expect nothing but words, or peraduenture ≈øome Troupes hired with their owne ≈øiluer. He ≈øaid al≈øo that the King his Ma≈øter oppo≈øed him≈øelfe to the Treaty of Peace with the Hollanders, to enfeeble ≈øo much the more the Succours which the Pope might otherwi≈øe haue from Spaine: but that the Catholique King would abandon all other enterpri≈øes to increa≈øe his power for the maintenance of Religion: That not with≈øtanding he hoped to be able for the ≈øeruice of God to doe both the one and the other, making ready 50000. ≈øouldiers which would ≈øuffice both for Italy and the Low Countries: That he would leuie 45. Companies of foot to ≈øend into Italie vnder Don Ferdinand of Toledo: That he would draw the men of Warre out of Sicily, Naples, and Milan, and gather more out of Germanie and Sui≈ø≈øerland, being re≈øolued not to aband on the Pope: That he would haue the King of Great-Britaine vnder≈øtand, that the aide which he intended to the Republique ≈øhould be to ≈ømall
purpo≈øe, fora≈ømuch as they had not forces an≈øwerable to report: That their great trea≈øure was a brag: That their ≈øubiects were di≈øcontent, and de≈øirous to change the Gouernment. That the Signiory had no Captaines of reputation, the Catholique King hauing with him all the Italian Princes, vnle≈ø≈øe they had recour≈øe to ≈øome hereticall Prince, which would render them odious both to the People and the Souldiers. All this was ≈øpoken, to the end that the Republique, ≈øeeing them≈øelues for≈øaken by all, ≈øhould yeeld more ea≈øily to that which the Pope de≈øired.

Now at Venice men beleeued for certaine, that the Differences with Rome could not admit of any Concord, and that the pre≈øent yeere would not pa≈ø≈øe with ≈øuch tranquillitie as the former had enioyned, which was wholly ≈øpent in Treaties and Di≈øputes. Which they feared ≈øo much the more, becau≈øe the Leuies of men of Warre within the State of Milan euery day increa≈øed. And though ≈øome imagined vndoubtedly (as al≈øo the euent afterward ≈øhewed,) that all this was done to no other end then to con≈øtraine the Republique onely for feare to yeeld vnto the Popes demands, or rather by the≈øe
apparences to giue him content or to oblige him farther; not with≈øtanding this produced a contrary effect in the ≈øpirits of the Venetians, who re≈øolued to ha≈øten with more courage the preparations of Warre, and to make ready all their Troupes, Italians and Albans, with ≈øome others of the Vltramontans. They determined al≈øo to elect a Secretary to be ≈øent to the Count de Vaudemont, as well to giue the fir≈øt pay to the ≈øouldiers, as to write vnto him that he was to begin the Leuie: and they elected Iohn Baptista Padauin, who had beene employed to the ≈øame effect in the yeere 1601. who had Commi≈ø≈øion to make a Leuie of 6000. footmen, to wit, 3000. French, Lorraines and Wallons, and 3000. Dutch, although afterwards hee had commandement to let the Dutch alone, and to leuie 3000. naturall Sui≈ø≈øes, to whom hee was inioyned by the way to communicate the Differences of the Republique, and the occa≈øions which they had to make v≈øe of their Nation; and in particular hee had charge to doe the≈øe offices at Zurich, Ba≈øil and Berne, without lingring, that hee might quickly pa≈ø≈øe to Nancy, which was the principall aime of his iourney.

Verdelli being ≈øtill at Venice, where he had beene ≈øince Aprill of the former yeare, it was determined to let him know, that if the Controuer≈øies with the Pope pa≈ø≈øed on further, the Republique ≈øhould haue need to ≈øerue them≈øelues of men beyond the Mountaines; and therefore that he ≈øhould aduerti≈øe the Count de Vaudemont his Ma≈øter, to take ≈øo good order with his Affaires, that he might on all occa≈øions cau≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe into Italy ≈øuch numbers of Souldiers, as the Republique ≈øhould require for their ≈øeruice. Verdelli an≈øwered, that the men were ready, and that they ≈øhould be more troubled to retaine them that were ≈øuperfluous, than to ≈øend them that were required: That for the pa≈ø≈øage, the Count his Ma≈øter would let them pa≈ø≈øe ≈øecurely by the way of the Sui≈ø≈øes and Gri≈øons. And hee ≈øaid moreouer, that it was fit to giue aduice to the Duke of Lorraine touching the occurrences and ≈øtate of the Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and that he would take it as a ≈øingular fauour, Which accordingly the Senate executed ≈øpeedily, commanding their Amba≈ø≈øador, who was with the Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, to ≈øend to Lorraine, and to ≈øignifie vnto tho≈øe Princes the ≈øtate of the Republique, to make remon≈øtrance of their mo≈øt iu≈øt Rea≈øons, and the
wrongs which they had ≈øuffered by the Pope: and to let that Count vnder≈øtand, that he ≈øhould prouide things nece≈ø≈øary, to the end that when the time ≈øhould require, and when the Republique ≈øhould giue him notice, he might be ready to tran≈øport Souldiers which ≈øhould bee demanded.

When the Amba≈ø≈ø. of Venice in France receiued this coÃÑmandement, the Count de Vaudemont was at Paris with the King, to adui≈øe him of the Mariage of the Duke of Bar his Brother, with the Daughter of the Duke of Mantua: wherefore the Amba≈ø≈øadour had opportunity to aduerti≈øe him according to his charge. To which he an≈øwered that the Rea≈øons of the Republique were full of hone≈øty, and the in≈øtances of the Pope very vnrea≈øonable, and that he would not faile to ≈øend ≈øuch numbers of Souldiers as were required. The Amba≈ø≈øador al≈øo ≈øent to the Duke of Lorraine the Secretary Dominico Dominici, who being arriued the ≈øecond of Iune at Nancy, communicated vnto the Duke what had pa≈ø≈øed between the Pope and the Republique, and the great Rea≈øons which vrged the Republique to maintaine their Lawes, and their ancient Authority to iudge the Eccle≈øia≈øtiques. The Duke te≈øtified, that he receiued
gratefully the Honour which the Republique had done him in this Communication, and inlarged him≈øelfe amply in the prai≈øes of their Prudence, and of their Religion; adioyning for the particulars of the matters in di≈øpute, that if the Cardinall his Sonne would make purcha≈øes within his Lands without his permi≈ø≈øion, he would not endure it. And for iudging Eccle≈øia≈øtiques, he ≈øaid, That it was practi≈øed in his E≈øtate, and in all France: and as it was meet for them to ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe others in innocence, ≈øo ought they ≈øo much more to be re≈øtrained to right cour≈øes by feare of paines. Touching the Souldiers which they de≈øired, he an≈øwered that the Count his Sonne was at the Seruice of the Republique, as al≈øo all his hor≈øe ≈øhould be ready to the ≈øame purpo≈øe. Parti≈øans continued to moue euill humors, and procure ≈øeditions, not onely by fal≈øe reports (which preuaile much among ba≈øe people,) but further by gifts and pre≈øents, which corrupt tho≈øe who cannot be deceiued. In Spaine they ob≈øerued the danger of the≈øe running rumors; therefore at that ≈øame time when the King permitted the Count de Fuentes to draw out 10000. Musketiers, he writ vnto him withall, that ≈øeeing the danger of Warre by the di≈ø≈øentions betweene the Pope and the Republique, to diuert it he had declared him≈øelfe for the Pope, that he might merit well of the Holy See, and cau≈øe him to conde≈øcend and accept the conditions which he refu≈øed: That to this purpo≈øe he had ≈øent Don Francis de Ca≈øtro to Venice, where finding greater re≈øi≈øtance then he had thought, he had giuen him charge to vnite his offices with tho≈øe of other Princes. But the difficulties ≈øtill growing, he had beene willing to try the la≈øt remedy, which was to ≈øhew him≈øelfe intere≈ø≈øed for the Church, and by this meanes to take from the Republique their hopes grounded vpon the Popes feeblene≈ø≈øe. But fora≈ømuch as this was ≈øini≈øterly interpreted by ≈øome ill affeoted, he was re≈øolued to publi≈øh this his Deliberation (giuing
notice thereof to his Mini≈øters,) to wit, that they ≈øhould not take deca≈øious, how fit ≈øoeuer, to ≈øo ment the Warre.

Among the Gri≈øons, the Mutiners were now to the number of 2000 among≈øt whom a bruit was cunningly ≈øeattered, that the Repub. of Venice had bought the pa≈ø≈øage for 80000 crowns, and therefore they would know by who≈øe hands this money had pa≈ø≈øed. Vpon which occa≈øion the Re≈øident of Venice finding him≈øelfe not ≈øafe at Coira, purpo≈øed to retire him≈øelfe to To≈øana. But the Muriners, without any re≈øpect, came 200. of them into his Hou≈øe and ≈øtaied him, ≈øaying, That it was no time to be going, but to giue them account who they were that had receiued the money from the Signiory of Venice, and pa≈ø≈øed to very in≈øolent ≈øpeeches; whereupon the Re≈øident was forced to retire him≈øelfe. He made complaint of this affront to the Councell, requiring that they might be cha≈øti≈øed; but in the Councell there was neither power nor vertue, the principall of them and mo≈øt couragious being ab≈øent, ≈øome hauing retired them≈øelues becau≈øe of the≈øe ≈øtirres, and others being in the Valtoline or in Amba≈ø≈øage Notwith≈øtanding tho≈øe of the Councell offered
him a conuoy to conduct him to To≈øana, with which being on the way, he was encountred by a multitude of people, who con≈øtrained him to returne into his Hou≈øe, where he was guarded as a pri≈øoner, not ≈øuffered to write or receiue a Letter: Onely to ≈øweeten a little this barbarous v≈øage, they gaue him foure Gentlemen to beare him company. Afterward a rumor was rai≈øed that the Lorraines were in the field, and ≈øaid that they would open the pa≈ø≈øage by force if it were not yeelded in amity; which renewed againe the mutiny, ≈øo as the multitude came with ≈øuch fury to the Re≈øidents hou≈øe, that he could hardly be defended by his guard. The Parti≈øans of Spaine, although they were bankrupt, yet cea≈øed not to ≈øcatter money and put in Armes their Adherents; but with all this they could not hinder, but that the multitude at length gaue care to better coun≈øell, and was per≈øwaded to expect the a≈ø≈øembly of all the Companies, and in the meane while to free the Re≈øident, vpon promi≈øe that he ≈øhould arrend the A≈ø≈øembly. It was the ≈øeuenth day after he had beene forced that he was ≈øet at liberty; but by and by after followed a new encounter. For the ≈øouldiers that had beene leuied for the ≈øeruice of the Republique
cited their Captaines, and commanded them to giue their pay; which forced the Re≈øudent to giue the Captaines 2000. Crownes for this effect, and by that meanes the Sedition was pacified, and in the interim the Troupes or Companies were a≈ø≈øembled.

In Spaine, becau≈øe the Negotiation of Don Francis de Ca≈øtro did not ≈øucceed as they de≈øired, and ≈øince the Duke of Sauoy made continuall in≈øtances to the King, that he would approue his iourney to Venice, they re≈øolued at length to giue way vnto him, although they held him rather a Souldier then a fit in≈øtrument of Peace, thinking it al≈øo dangerous to deny him ≈øuch a demand. Notwith≈øtanding they gaue him an ambiguous an≈øwer, as beleeuing not that he would Treat conformably to the intention of Spaine, but that as a ≈øouldier hee thought to be employed in the Warre by one of the Parties, rather then to agree them. And becau≈øe they began to ≈øu≈øpect that the Pope relying vpon the ≈øuccours of Spaine would refu≈øe too ≈øtifly to admit a Concord, the Catholique King aduerti≈øed the Nuntio by his Mini≈øters, that, to the end they might be more ready in Italy, he had giuen order vnto all the Captaines
(who were retired to repo≈øe them≈øelues in their hou≈øes,) that they ≈øhould pre≈øent them≈øelues with all the power they could vpon the confines of France, and had al≈øo written vnto the Viceroys of Bar√ßelona and of Nauarre, that they ≈øhould put all the Forces they could po≈ø≈øibly in the Forts vpon the Frontiers. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe they adioyned, that it would well become the Pope, for diuer≈øion of the≈øe broyles and dangers, to ≈øupport ≈øome ≈ømall faults in his children, though to him they ≈øeemed great. And a few daies after on another occa≈øion they told the Nuntio, that the King ≈øhould doe more ≈øeruice vnto the Apo≈øtolique See by repre≈ø≈øing the Heretiques in the Low Countries, then by fomenting the troubles of Italy, and that ≈øo much the more as the Pope ≈øhould bee a≈ø≈øi≈øted by Spaine, ≈øo much the more ≈øtraitly would the Venetians league them≈øelues with the enemies of the Catholique faith: wherefore it was good aduice, that the Pope ≈øhould neglect his owne priuate intere≈øts for the vniuer≈øall good of Chri≈øtendome. In conclu≈øion, to ≈øpeake more clearely, they ≈øaid, that it did not be≈øeeme the Father of all Chri≈øtendome to ground a Warre ≈øo cruell and pernicious to Chri≈øtian people, vpon a King
≈øo pious, and that his Holine≈ø≈øe would aba≈øe the Apo≈øtolique Dignitie, if he ≈øu≈øtained by humane meanes the Authority which God had giuen him. They ≈øaid further, that it was meet to recompence the King with ≈øome thing for the Declaration which he had made, ≈øince thereby he had drawne vpon him≈øelfe ≈øo many enemies: aiming herein either at the Tenths of the Realme of Naples, or at the remitting of the Fief. It is certaine that this newes extremely troubled the Pope, ≈øeeing them when there was no need to make ≈øo liberall offers, and in time of nece≈ø≈øitie thus to retire.

But in Lorraine, the Count de Vaudemont fell ≈øicke. Some attributed the cau≈øe thereof to a wound which he had receiued in his head, cha≈øing a Hart a yeare before, whereby he lo≈øt a good quantity of bloud; and others to the vexations which he receiued by the importunities of ≈øo many in different places. In the meane while, Aduices came from Italy, that the Di≈ø≈øentions were likely to be accommodated. Montagu the Re≈øident at Venice for the great Duke, writ vnto the Duke of Lorraine, that the Cardinal de Ioyeu≈øe and Fre≈øne had a≈ø≈øured him that the Accord would certainly follow their Negotiation; but
that they kept it ≈øecret, becau≈øe being knowne, if it were not agreeable to all, it might be interrupted. The Duke vi≈øited the Count de Vaudemont, and comforted him with this aduice, promi≈øing him that the Secretary Padauin would returne contented. And calling Him to ≈øpeak with him vpon this aduice, fir≈øt he excu≈øed him≈øelfe for deferring to Treat with him, becau≈øe he was hindered by the Diet: then told him that from Rome and from France he had certaine aduice that the Peace was vpon concluding. That the Preparations at Milan and Rome were ≈ølackened, and ≈øo the occa≈øion of the Leuie cea≈øed. And how≈øoeuer hee had a charge to ≈øollicite it, neuerthele≈ø≈øe things now being vpon termes of Concord, he ought to ≈øurcea≈øe vntill he had further coÃÑmandemeÃÑt. That his inteÃÑtion was very good, and that he would not deferre to prepare him≈øelfe, but onely to ≈øpare them charges: praying him to repre≈øent vnto the Republique this his good office and coun≈øell which he gaue with ≈øincerity. The Secretary thanked him, but withall wi≈øhed him to con≈øider that oftentimes rumours of Peace were ≈øcattered, which in effect vani≈øh into ≈ømoake; and that the Pope was then farthe≈øt off, when he ≈øeemed to be the neare≈øt;
That the Republique hauing yeelded ≈øomething, in ≈øtead of being appea≈øed he required yet more: That the Pope hauing publi≈øhed in Con≈øi≈øtory his finall re≈øolution to the Warre, vanting him≈øelfe of the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Princes, and naming a Legate, this had made the Republique to Arme for the common repo≈øe: That the diligence which the Count had te≈øtified of his willingne≈ø≈øe to ≈øerue them, had moued the Senate to ≈øend Him into Lorraine; That none knew better their nece≈ø≈øities than the Republique them≈øelues, & that his Highne≈ø≈øe ought to beleeue him, knowing well that the Senate would not ca≈øt them≈øelues vpon needle≈ø≈øe expences. Wherefore it was not to the purpo≈øe to write vnto Venice that the Leuie might be deferred, but rather to take ≈øuch order that he might write that their Souldiers were ready in the field. The Duke replied, that what he had ≈øaid of the Peace was vpon good ground, & that he de≈øired this ≈øatisfaction that he would write according to his coun≈øell, e≈øpecially ≈øince the indi≈øpo≈øition of the Count his Sonne might di≈øpen≈øe with his employment for ≈øome few dayes. Hereupon Padauin con≈øented to write by an expre≈ø≈øe Currier, ≈øaying, he hoped that the Count being recouered, while≈øt they expected
an an≈øwer, would then take order to make the Leuy. To which the Duke an≈øwered nothing; and not with≈øtanding that many times, euen by interrogations, the Secretary was in≈øtant to haue an an≈øwer, whether the Count did ≈øeriou≈øly intend, as al≈øo the Duke his Father, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, yet he could draw nothing from them. The Count ≈øent to ≈øee whether the Secretary were ≈øatisfied by the Duke; to whom He an≈øwered, That he was to attend his recouery, that they made prayers for his health at Venice, whither he had written, a≈ø≈øuring the Republique of his ≈øeruice; which gaue the Count great comfort, and the Duke thanked Padauin, ≈øaying, That hee would acknowledge his Sonne owed his life vnto him.

About this time Criuelli, Chamberlaine to the Duke of Bauier, arriued at Nancy, bringing with him a Breue from the Pope, by which were renued the in≈øtances made vnto the Count, to withdraw him≈øelfe from the Seruice of the Republique. He had Audience of all ≈øeuerally with contentment. The Count would not be ≈øeene by him, excu≈øing him≈øelfe by rea≈øon of his indi≈øpo≈øition; but ≈øome dayes after being much importuned, he receiued him with condition, that he
≈øhould ≈øpeake but little, and be content with a ≈øhort an≈øwer, without replying. He had then Audience, where he endeuoured to moue the Count by Rea≈øons of Religion and of State; To which the Count an≈øwered, that he had a care of his Honour, which was in ≈øuch ≈øort ioyned with Religion, that they could not be ≈øeparated. Padauin met this Criuelli at the Church, who v≈øed to him courteous words, ≈øaying, That the Duke his Ma≈øter de≈øired Peace, and that for this effect he had appointed publique Prayers, and that he proiected to goe in Pilgrimage, and that he hoped Peace would follow, con≈øidering that the Spaniards really de≈øired it, both for the affaires of Flanders, and for the Election of the King of Romanes.

div.head: SEVENTH BOOKE.
div.p:
WHile≈øt Padauin expected an an≈øwer from Venice, Moun≈øieur de Ba≈ø≈øompierre arriued at the Court of the Duke of Lorraine, to ≈øpeake by word of mouth with that Secretary, & from thence to
pa≈ø≈øe vnto the Seruice of the Republique, according as he had promi≈øed to the Amba≈ø≈ø. Priuli. And he brought this newes vnto the Count, that when he took leaue of the King, his Maie≈øty de≈øired him to tel him in his behalfe, that he could not ≈øaue his Reputation, if he failed the Republique, much le≈ø≈øe finde any apparant pretext to excu≈øe him≈øelfe. Further, he gaue him aduice that the Duke of Gui≈øe offered him≈øelfe to be his Lieutenant, and that a great number of Souldiers were prouided to got with him, the King being willing to giue licen≈øe to all except his Officers. There was one expre≈ø≈øely ≈øent vnto the Count from the Canton of Schaffu≈øa, who offered Him a Leuie of men, and all other commodities. Marinuille al≈øo returned from Florence, bringing certaine hopes of a Concord, which was further confirmed by a Currier di≈øpatched with diligence vnto the Duke, with aduice that the Cardinall de Ioyeu≈øe hauing receiued all contentment, was to depart from Venice to goe to the Pope But the Currier being come from Venice with an≈øwer, Padauin complained vnto the Count in the Name of the Republique, for that the Souldiers were not ready as he had promi≈øed, and pre≈ø≈øed him to make ha≈øte, in remedy of his former
≈ølackne≈ø≈øe. The Count hereat was a≈øtoni≈øhed, and an≈øwered that he had done his duty before, if the Duke his Father had permitted him, with whom it was meet to ≈øpeake. Padauin replied, that he would doe ≈øo, for ≈øo he had order; but that he had fir≈øt addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe to him, as to the Principall; that he would retaine the Currier a day or two, to the end that he might ab≈øolutely ≈øend his an≈øwer, not of complements or excu≈øes, but of effects. The Father and a ‚Ä¢ d his Sonnes a≈ø≈øembled in Coun≈øell vpon the an≈øwer which they were to giue. The Cardinall fir≈øt began, and ≈øaid, That their Hou≈øe had bin alwaies deuoted to the Church, again≈øt which none of their Family euer carried Armes, and that they ought not now to do otherwi≈øe; That this were to bla≈øt their Reputation, and incurre the vniuer≈øall hatred of Catholiques, be≈øides the danger of running into Cen≈øures, which were terrible, ≈øetting before their eyes the great Troubles of the Duke of Bar, for marying Madame Catharine, the Kings Si≈øter: And much exaggerating the≈øe Rea≈øons, he concluded that they ought openly to deny Padauin that which he de≈øired, and that this might be a cau≈øe of Peace, con≈øidering that the Repub. ≈øeeing them≈øelues defeated of this
≈øuccour, would humble them≈øelues vnto the pope. The Duke of Bar was of the ≈øame opinion with the Cardinall, adding withall, that it was fit to finde ≈øome temperament by which they might ≈øaue the Reputation of the Count. The Count him≈øelfe con≈øidered on the one ≈øide, what had beene told him from the King of France, and from others who admoni≈øhed him of his engagement; and on the other, what had beene written from Tu≈øcany; and concluded that they ≈øhould well weigh how farre he was obliged, for that he ought to preferre his obligation to all other con≈øiderations. The Father ≈øaid, that he felt in him≈øelfe a very great combate; for the Rea≈øons of Religion and State did not permit that any of His ≈øhould take Armes again≈øt the Church, and e≈øpecially when other Catholique Princes would not doe it; Be≈øides, that the Warres of Italy would be the ruine of Chri≈øtendome. But on the other ≈øide, he de≈øired to giue ≈øome contentment to the Republique; yet he preferred ≈øtill the con≈øiderations of his Hou≈øe to all others. Vpon this ground he was re≈øolued, ≈øince he could not ≈øatisfie them with words, to abide all euill accidents that could happen, rather than giue way to this Leuie.
Wherefore, when Padauin came to the Audience which the Duke gaue him in pre≈øence of the Duke of Bar his Sonne, where He declared, that although at Venice they greatly maruelled why the Souldiers were no ≈øooner in readine≈ø≈øe, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe they were per≈øwaded that this default would be recompen≈øed with a greater diligence: The Duke an≈øwered, that he accounted the Peace to be in a manner concluded, and therefore there needed no more words; That the Republique hauing their Affaire accommodated, the Cen≈øures would fall on his Hou≈øe: That for this cau≈øe they ought not to bring mole≈øtation vpon others without any fruit; ≈øeeing that the more he de≈øired to gratifie the Republique vpon all occurrences, ≈øo much the more ≈øory was hee that he could not permit his Children to ≈øerue again≈øt the Church; That on other occa≈øions he and his Children would be alwaies ready to employ them≈øelues with all their forces for the ≈øeruice of the Republique. Padauin apprehending the Negatiue ≈øo clearely, iudged it nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øpeake plainly, and ≈øaid, That the reports of Peace were without ground; that if they had beene true, he ≈øhould not haue had ≈øo many
Commandments ≈øo often reiterated to ≈øollicite them, and although the Peace might follow vpon the Treaty, yet the Count denying the ≈øeruice which he owed, might render it difficult, becau≈øe the Pope hereby might be more hardned: That the Republique had not pre≈ø≈øed this Leuie ≈øo much, if they had not e≈øteemed it nece≈ø≈øarie: That who≈øoeuer puts him≈øelfe in the ≈øeruice of a Prince, ought to obey, not taking vpon him to iudge whether that which hee commandeth be nece≈ø≈øary and conuenient, or not: That the feare of Cen≈øures was but a vanity, becau≈øe they knew certainly that the Pope would acknowledge his error, and keepe him≈øelfe from the like hereafter: That if Excommunication were valide in all ca≈øes, Princes were vndone: That it was not meet to pre≈øuppo≈øe infallibility in Popes, ≈øince God often permits wicked Ones for the cha≈øti≈øement of the world: That the obligation of the Count by the con≈øent of the Duke his Father had beene contracted in time of Contentions; wherefore if he had no feare to promi≈øe it, he ought not to feare the execution of it. And he adioyned, that the Duke hauing demanded ≈øo much re≈øpite, as they might write and receiue an≈øwer, he knew not
how they could come to a refu≈øall without breach of word. The Duke an≈øwered, that he held the Peace for a≈ø≈øured, and euery houre expected to heare of the Conclu≈øion. After two houres audience, where pa≈ø≈øed many an≈øwers and replies on the one part and the other, the Duke continuing ≈øtill to ≈øay, that he expected the Conclu≈øion, Padauin told him, that if they re≈øolued to ≈øay nothing el≈øe they ≈øhould declare them≈øelues, that he might immediately depart to prouide el≈øe where for the ≈øeruice of his Prince, ≈øince he could obtaine nothing froÃÑ Them that were obliged. Vpon this the Duke praied him to wait three or foure daies. The next morning Padauin had audience of the Count, who at the fir≈øt fight told him, that he de≈øired death rather then to be in this e≈øtate, which hee neuer beleeued would haue hapned: That hee could not di≈ø≈øemble his griefe, for that he ≈øaw on the one ≈øide his owne engagement, and on the other the will of his Father, whom he dur≈øt not contradict: That the Breues of the Pope, & the pur≈øuits of many, e≈øpecially of the Ie≈øuites, had put ≈øcruples into the Dukes mind, wth he could not aboli≈øh, being aged & ≈øubject torecciue impre≈ø≈øions of terror: That he coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe of the Republique
had iu≈øt cau≈øe to complaine of him for the money which he had receiued, ≈øeeing he failed them in time of need; but he prote≈øted that it was not his fault, and praied Padauin to condale with him, and ≈øpake with ≈øuch affection that teares fell from him. Padauin, comforted him and ≈øaid, That in aduer≈øitie it was needfull to v≈øe prudence, and that he mu≈øt complaine of the Pope who ≈øold away his reputation by meanes of his Father. Hee repeated vnto him the ≈øame things which he had ≈øaid to the Duke, with greater vehomence and confidence, exhorting him to make a new tryall with his, Father to take away all impediment, to the ≈øend that ≈øuch an action, which would blemi≈øh his honour, might not come to the knowledge of men. Vpon the≈øe words the Count promi≈øed to v≈øe all his power with the Duke his Father, but withall remembred him that his Father by I en≈øon of his yeares was feeble in body and mind, and oppre≈ø≈øed with the ≈øugge≈øtions of diuers. Padauin ≈øaw well that all this was nought but artifices; wherefore hauing waited the foure daies, he demanded Audience to take his leaue, which they prolonged, to ≈øerue them≈øelues of time. But in the end being con≈øtrained to dilcourer
them≈øelues, the Count propo≈øed this motion, That a Leuie ≈øhould be made vpon promi≈øe that the men ≈øhould not ≈øerue again≈øt the Pope, and this onely to take away the ≈øcruple of the Duke his Father; obliging him≈øelfe that when once the ≈øouldiers were in Italy they ≈øhould obey the commandements of the Republique without re≈øeruation. This Padauin would not accept, that he might not violate the Capitulation, which was to ≈øerue Contra quo≈øcunque. So he re≈øolued to pa≈ø≈øe into Suitzerland, pre≈øently after he was adui≈øed where he might finde the Deputies of the Cantons.

The Pope in the meane while during the≈øe Differences, neglected not any thing which might ≈øu≈øteine his Dignity. For hauing learned out of the writings of the Venetians, that at Genoa was a Law altogether conformable to that of Venice, which forbade Eccle≈øiastiques to purcha≈øe, he made in≈øtance that it might be reuoked. Which the Republique readily obeyed, to doe a thing gratefull to his Holine≈ø≈øe, and to ≈øhew that the reuocation of their Edicts made the yeare before, as we haue formerly ≈øaid, had proceeded from a free di≈øpo≈øition, beleeuing al≈øo hereby to render the cau≈øe of the Venetian
Republique more odious. And vpon the like in≈øtance of the Pope, they gaue aduice of this reuocation in Spaine by their Amba≈ø≈øador, which was e≈øteemed in that Court for an extreme affectation, whereby it appeared manife≈øtly that herein they would giue example not onely to Venice, but to Portugall al≈øo, to Arragon, and to the King him≈øelfe.

The Duke of Sauoy ≈øignified vnto the Catholique King by Iames Antony de la Tour his Amba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary arriued a little before in Spaine, to giue aduice of a Mariage concluded betweene his Daughter and the Duke of Mantua, that he had accepted the In≈øtructions of the Emperour to be Mediator of the Differences betweene the Pope and the Republique of Venice. To which the King an≈øwered in generall terms; but the Duke of Lerma commended him for that he obeyed the Emperour, that the King had ≈øo great a de≈øire of the Agreement, that he praied God to grant him good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, that ≈øo good an effect might be produced by his meanes. The Duke without expecting any further, publi≈øhed his voyage, and gaue order to his Court, to make ready. Whereupon at Venice the bruit of his comming euery day more and more increa≈øed,
and the Duke ≈øent to Venice, Iohn Bapti≈øta Soluro with Letters of credence of 27. of February, to giue notice vnto the Senate, how the Emperour had ≈øent to Turin the Marquis of Ca≈øtillon, to ≈øollicite him to pa≈ø≈øe to Venice for the accommodating of the≈øe Differences: which being willing to vndertake, as well to obey the Emperour, as to ≈øerue the Republique, he was determined to defer no longer, but immediatly to begin his iourney, hoping that the Republique would well accept his comming and his interpo≈øing. That he had ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øador to this end, to certifie the Republique of his good will and of the diligence which he would v≈øe. Audience was giuen to this Amba≈ø≈øadar on the 11. of March with a courteous an≈øwer, that the Senate tooke in good part the comming of his Highne≈ø≈øe.
